(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, November 8th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

We have breaking news to report this morning. There's been a mass shooting in a California bar. At least 12 people have been killed including a sheriff's deputy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GEOFF DEAN, VENTURY COUNTY SHERIFF: Sergeant Helus died at the -- the sergeant passed away at the hospital about an hour ago.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Ventura County sheriff's spokesman says that the gunman is also dead. We will bring you the very latest developments as they come in, in California.

Plus, Jeff Sessions fired -- what's next for the Department of Justice and the Russia investigation? That's coming up.

New overnight -- a new era for Tesla. The company replacing Elon Musk as chairman with Robyn Denholm. We are looking at her tough job ahead of her of keeping Musk in line.

And then hit send too soon? Facebook now has a fix for that. How you can unsend messages through Facebook.

Markets this morning are pulling back after that powerful rally yesterday. Take a look at markets right now with futures indicating a lower opening for the broader averages. Dow Industrials set to be down 60 points at the start of trading, a quarter of a percent lower. The Nasdaq is down a half of a percent, 37 points lower. Investors are waiting on the Federal Reserve decision that's due today at 2:15 p.m. Eastern.

Meanwhile, yesterday big day -- stocks rallied sharply. Dow Industrials yesterday was up better than 500 points.

European markets -- no follow through today. The FT 100 is up 21 points but the CAC 40 is down a half a point and the DAX index is down 18 points.

In Asia overnight, markets mostly higher overnight. Take a look. Asian markets as you can see, the Shanghai composite was lower but Japan was up almost 2 percent.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me to break it all down -- Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell; Townhall.com political editor, Fox News contributor Guy Benson; and the "Wall Street Journal" editor at large, Gerry Baker. Good to see you this morning.

GERRY BAKER, EDITOR AT LARGE, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Thank you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us.

BAKER: Yes, thank you.

GUY BENSON, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Horrific news.

BARTIROMO: Horrific news on the shooting. And of course, there are other issues to talk about. But we've been following all morning this mass shooting in California, 12 people have been killed; 13 if you count the gunman. Among the dead, the sheriff's deputy.

Lauren Simonetti with all the details right now -- Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes, it's the middle of the night in California where we have learned that at least 12 people including that sheriff's deputy are dead. A gunman opened fire at a country music bar in Thousand Oaks, California. That's about 40 miles west of Los Angeles.

The scene is contained. The shooter is dead inside the building. They did find a handgun. They did not find an assault rifle but they do continue to search. Authorities say hundreds of people were inside the Borderline Bar and Grill because it was hosting a college country night.

We're going to show you some witnesses, describing the chaos that they heard and they experienced after those shots were fired.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I just started hearing these big pops -- pop, pop, pop. There was probably three or four. I hit the ground. I look up. The security guard's dead. I don't want to say dead but he was shot. He was down. And the gunman was throwing smoke grenades all over the place.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: You have to remember, this was college night. So the families of these victims are being notified. It is horrific. It is heart- wrenching.

And that's what you heard from Sheriff Geoff Dean as he was telling us about his friend, the sergeant deputy who died in that bar.

So, he was 29 years on the force. It really is a heart-wrenching story -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Ok. Lauren -- thank you. And we'll come back to you as news develops.

Joining me right now is Texas Congressman Louie Gohmert. Congressman Gohmert -- good to see you this morning. Thanks very much for joining us.

REP. LOUIE GOHMERT (R), TEXAS: Good to see you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Obviously, you are the vice chairman of the Judiciary Subcommittee on Crime, Terrorism and Homeland Security. Your reaction to this horrific news that we're reporting this morning and how do you stop something like this?

GOHMERT:: Well, John Adams said it clearly back in 1796 as our second president. Our constitution was intended for a moral and religious people. It is wholly inadequate for the governing of any other. And we have to get back to teaching right and wrong.

But right now, our hearts and prayers do go out to family members and those who experienced this horrific shooting. And the deputy that just -- I mean, I know hundreds -- I've worked with hundreds of law enforcement and it's still just -- I tear up when I think about guys that run to the sound of the guns instead of running the other direction.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

GOHMERT:: Real heroes. And we heard the sheriff say we don't know if there's terrorism. Well, we know that there was terrorism. Somebody comes in with smoke bombs and wanting to shoot multiple people, clearly they intended -- that person intended to terrorize.

But of course, we know terrorism is a euphemism for radical Islam. And the sheriff is -- what he was really saying is we don't know if it was radical Islam like the shooting at the bar in Orlando.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GOHMERT:: But that is yet to be determined.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

GOHMERT:: But when you wear black. You're bringing smoke grenades, clearly it was premeditated murder. And it's unfortunate that we don't have the chance to actually put him to death. I don't know that that would have happened in California.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GOHMERT:: But right now, for all the victims, there is just so much shock and so much hurting and I've seen enough of it in my life. It never gets easier.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: No, it doesn't. and it's really hard to watch the witnesses, very tearful, talking about what they saw. It's just an incredible story. And we will find the motive and bring it to our viewers.

Want to switch gears and ask about the divided Congress, sir. Because Democrats retook the House obviously or they're retaking the House. Republicans are gearing up for anticipated -- some hurdles on issues from taxes to trade.

The President and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi both spoke out yesterday on plans for bipartisanship. Listen to this. I've got to get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I give her a great deal of credit for what she's done and what she's accomplished. Hopefully we can all work together next year to continue delivering for the American people.

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA), HOUSE MINORITY LEADER: We, as Democrats, are here to strengthen the institution in which we serve and not to have it be a rubber stamp for President Trump. We believe that we have a responsibility to seek common ground where we can; where we cannot, we must stand our ground.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: I know there's a lot of planning yesterday -- Congressman, with Republicans, party leaders, trying to map this course for the divided Congress. How is this going to look with now the Democrats in the majority in the House?

GOHMERT:: Well actually, Maria -- it's been a divided Congress for the last nearly two years. It's just that in the past two years, it's been divided between a majority of the Republicans in the House and what we wanted to do to build a wall where it was needed, to secure the border, to avoid amnesty, those kind of things -- that was what the majority of Republicans wanted to do. And then the division was with our own leadership that we're not going to help the President accomplish his major promises that got him elected president.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GOHMERT:: So this time now, it will be divided come January between political parties. But I'm delighted to hear Nancy Pelosi talk in those terms. It beats the heck out of the Democrat chairman over Energy and Commerce that handled the Obamacare when Republicans were saying look, let's work together on dealing with pre-existing conditions --

BARTIROMO: Right.

GOHMERT:: -- and taking care of people through age 26. I was ok going 30 or 40 if you're living with your parents.

But the chairman said we don't need Republican -- we don't want Republican input and we don't need Republican votes. And so it's really nice to hear Nancy Pelosi talking in these terms. We'll see how long that lasts.

BARTIROMO: All right. Let me turn to Jeff Sessions. Some people are saying look, this is right here, one of the first things that the Democrats are going to be complaining about, and they are. The President fired the U.S. Attorney General, replacing him with Sessions' chief of staff, Matthew Whitaker yesterday. A permanent replacement expected to be nominated at a later date.

What's your reaction to this? Obviously, no surprise. We were all expecting Jeff Sessions to resign right after the midterm elections. But does this create a problem for the President, given we've already heard from the Democrats saying somebody else is overseeing the Mueller probe, we don't like it.

GOHMERT:: Well, the Democrats ought to love it because they should have seen that this was coming. And I love Jeff Sessions. He's a fine, decent, moral, ethical man. And I think he was a little naive in not appreciating the people that work for Rosenstein that wanted to diminish him in the President's eyes and gave him bad advice including to recuse himself.

He relied too heavily on the advice of people he called career but I would say were Democrat operatives, just been there a while.

But I was a little surprised. Matthew Whitaker's a great guy. He's a wonderful man. But Democrats ought to be loving Matt because his job as chief of staff to Jeff Sessions was to look out for Jeff Sessions and he did not keep him away from the bad advice of people that wanted to destroy Jeff. And so they ought to love the fact that Matt's been raised -- he didn't do a good job protecting his boss, Jeff, from the radicals -- and I'm not talking radical Islam, I'm just talking radical Democrats that loved Sally Yates, loved Obama, hated Trump. He should have protected Jeff better from bad advice and now he's going to be acting AG. And so they ought to be loving it.

BARTIROMO: I mean, agenda item number one will likely be ok, Robert Mueller, let's see what you have. Where are we on this? Where do you think we are in the Robert Mueller probe? How will Matthew Whitaker deal with this differently?

I mean in terms of the investigations going on in your chamber into the DOJ, the FBI, and that cabal of people who would tried to stop Donald Trump, where are those investigations? Do they go away at this point?

GOHMERT:: No, absolutely not. We need to conclude them and even though our -- well, in January the former speaker, the current speaker, his advice to us was when there's no drama, we win. When there's no drama, we win.

That's ridiculous. That's coming from somebody that wants to avoid a fight apparently because what we see is, and President Trump has shown it, when we fight, there's some drama but we win. And so our --

BARTIROMO: Well, they're going to be fighting with the President though -- Congressman. I mean we've heard from Gerry Nadler. We've heard from, you know, Elijah Cummings --

GOHMERT:: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- who are going to be -- and Adam Schiff who are going to be the leaders of, you know, the chairmen of some important committees there.

GOHMERT:: But they're not yet.

BARTIROMO: So what is the President going to do with all of these investigations that are going to pile up once the new Congress gets in session?

GOHMERT:: I heard someone say he's going to need to add more lawyers to the White House and I think he's right about that --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

GOHMERT:: -- because he's going to be overwhelmed with discovery requests and subpoenas.

BARTIROMO: So does anything get done for the American people legislatively, sir?

GOHMERT:: I sure hope so because I hope the Democrats don't make the mistake of hurting Americans like they did with Obamacare, destroying seniors' health care, removing $716 billion from Medicare.

BARTIROMO: What about immigration -- congressman? You've got a caravan crisis right now; thousands of troops are deployed at the border as we speak. The migrant caravan continues moving northbound from Mexico.

GOHMERT:: Now, the President is going to protect the country. He made that very clear when I was talking to him about it in Houston. He is going to protect the country. He doesn't need Congress to do that.

BARTIROMO: But don't you need the Democrats' help? They're now in charge of, you know, they're the majority in the House. I mean Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell weighed in on the future plans for the border wall funding yesterday. Here's what he said. I've got to get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SENATOR MITCH MCCONNELL (R-KY), SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: We're certainly going to try to help the President achieve what he would like to do with regard to the wall and border security. And that will obviously have to be done on some kind of bipartisan, excuse me, some kind of bipartisan discussion.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So I go back to the first question. I mean how is this going to work? Will you see bipartisan work together? You represent the people of Texas. Your take on this?

GOHMERT:: Well, we haven't seen any bipartisanship really at work here, even to the point that they would destroy an honorable man like Kavanaugh. So -- but hopefully there will be a change of heart. That's hope that springs eternal in him and Brett. And with God all things are possible.

But we just haven't seen any evidence that that's what they really want to do. But let's face it, I love hearing Mitch McConnell say we're going to help the President with a wall because I know the House leadership sure hasn't done that for the last nearly two years.

So we've got a little window here before we lose it and actually if we took a step we could pass funding for the wall without having to have cloture in the Senate. And I understand we're going to hopefully work on that.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll be watching. Congressman -- it's good to see you as always. Thanks so much, sir.

GOHMERT:: Great to see you. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Louie Gohmert joining us there.

Breaking news overnight, 12 people are dead including a sheriff's deputy after a gunman opened fire at a California bar. The very latest, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Breaking news this morning, a mass shooting in southern California.

Cheryl Casone with all the details now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: We've been following the story all morning -- Maria.

At least 12 people, including a sheriff's deputy, killed in a shooting at a country bar in southern California. The suspect, in addition, is dead. The shooting happening last night around 11:20 local time in Thousand Oaks, California. That's about 40 miles west of Los Angeles.

The bar was packed at the time with college students. They were hosting a college country night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DEAN: We have no idea if there's a terrorism link to this event or not. As you know, these are ongoing investigations and that information will come out as soon as we're able to determine exactly who the suspect was and what motive he might have had for this horrific event.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: All right. Talking about what the motive was and they don't know yet.

The officer who was killed identified as Ventura County Sheriff's Department Sergeant Ron Helus. He is survived by a wife and his son. He was actually getting ready to retire next year.

Also breaking overnight, Tesla's board has a new chair. Robyn Denholm is going to replace Elon Musk who'll step down from the position as part of a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Tesla had until November 13th to announce a new chairman under the SEC agreement which found that Musk's tweets in August about taking his company private were fraudulent.

Denholm has served on Tesla's board since 2014. Now, Elon Musk tweeted he "Would like to thank Robyn for joining the team. Great respect. Very much look forward to working together."

Taking a look at shares of Tesla in the premarket, down about a quarter percent.

And rising interest rates are making would-be home buyers nervous. The number of mortgage applications fell 4 percent last week to its lowest level since 2014. The Mortgage Bankers Association says applications to buy a home fell the most, by 5 percent; refinancing applications dropping 3 percent. Higher rates of course the result of the Federal Reserve raising interest rates eight times since December of 2015. And they are, of course, meeting this week as well -- Maria.

Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Yes. We will find out today but we're not expecting a rate hike today from that two-day meeting at the Fed.

Breaking overnight a deadly mass shooting in a California bar. A dozen people have been killed, including a sheriff's deputy when a gunman opened fire during a college night. The very latest straight ahead.

We are also keeping a watch on markets this morning, and earnings where the 2018 midterms had a big effect yesterday. Markets were up better than 500 points on the Dow. We've got that and a lot more. This morning, bit of a pullback.

Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We have breaking news this morning out of California. Twelve people have been killed including a sheriff's deputy in a mass bar shooting.

We are watching markets as well after yesterday's big rally. We're seeing a pullback this morning. Dow Industrials expected to be down about 50 points at the start of trading, down a quarter of a percent. The Nasdaq is down 31 after a huge rally yesterday on the midterm elections.

We are waiting on the Fed decision, of course. that's due out at 2:15 p.m. Eastern. We're not expecting the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates after a two-day meeting..

European indices are mixed. The FT 100 is up 26 points, the CAC in Paris was flat and the DAX index in Germany is down 20 as well.

And in Asia overnight markets finished mostly higher with the exception of China.

Joining us right now is Spruce Point Capital Management founder and chief investment officer, Ben Axler. And Ben -- it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

BEN AXLER, FOUNDER & CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, SPRUCE POINT CAPITAL MANAGEMENT: Thank you for having me.

BARTIROMO: Were you surprised at that big rally in stocks yesterday?

AXLER: Not at all. I think the market's base case was that the Democrats were going to take the house. Obviously political uncertainty is never good for markets. Markets got what they wanted. Now we move on to the Fed and interest rate.

BARTIROMO: Wo what would you do in terms of money right now? Do you want to put money into work in stocks or no?

AXLER: So we're -- we're a short selling firm. We play defense a lot. We think right now is not a great time to be overly exposed to stocks given where we are in the business cycle, rate rising cycle. We're in a lax regulatory environment as well.

We're focused really on companies that are flattering their numbers with aggressive counting (ph), receiving high valuations for speculative business models.

BARTIROMO: And just to be clear -- you're shorting those companies?

AXLER: Absolutely. We're shorting them with an activist bent. We put our research on our Web site and try to find, you know, the good companies from the bad companies.

BENSON: On the politics side, do you think the markets sort of like divided government where, you know, you have the tax cuts, you had the deregulation, things are doing very well in the economy so maybe some gridlock is sort of ok in Washington?

AXLER: That seems to always be the case, yes. I mean historically speaking, gridlock is somewhat bullish for markets. But we're really focused mosh on the rate-rising cycle. And think that the market is going to be more discriminating now.

The easy money is made in a lower rate-cutting environment. Rate-rising cycle -- the market is focused the quality of the companies, the valuations and how the companies are putting their capital to work.

BAKER: What about the tech sector? You know, the big tech companies took a bit of a beating in the last month or so, had some good bit of a recovery yesterday. I'm interested in your point about, you know, companies that are maybe have got some questionable numbers.

Where do you see now, because they've been so much behind the surge in equity prices in the last couple of years? And they now dominate many of the major indexes. Where do you see -- where do you see the major tech companies going in the next year or so?

AXLER: Yes. We had some really good success shorting tech companies this past month. The market is much more discriminating now on the quality of the business. So one of our best shorts was a company call To You (ph). It trades at 10 times revenues, losing $40 million a year, the stock was at an all-time high. Brokers putting $100 price target on it. Now, the stock's at $50.

So it really comes down now to the quality of the business. Are they making money? Do they have a path to profitability? And I think you're going to see more discrimination between those that have a real business model and those that don't.

BAKER: And rates do you see, you know, we're going to see the Fed today, the Fed's not going to do anything today. But you know, short-term rates gone up with long-term rates -- have gone up as well as the last year. How much is that starting -- I mean I don't see that's having an overall effect on the market -- but how does that affect some of the individual companies that you're look at? How do you weigh that as you look at --

AXLER: Tremendously. So we've had good success in the past month shorting companies with low or declining organic growth and a lot of debt, particularly companies exposed to short-term debt.

We recently shorted a company call Dollarama in Canada, $1.8 billion of debt coming due in the next 24 months. The companies is discounting the companies that are going to have to refinance; they're going to have to refinance at a higher rate. The market's discriminating between those with longer term maturities and those were shorter.

BARTIROMO: Are you short Tesla?

AXLER: We're not short Tesla. We try to find companies that have a less crowded short position. You know, as we've seen, Tesla's a battle ground stock, it can move 10, 15, 20 percent on a tweet from, you know, Elon Musk. We're trying to find situations where the market doesn't already know what the short pieces (ph) is, less crowding, lower short squeeze risk.

MCDOWELL: What are some other shorts that are too crowded for you to really want to anticipate?

AXLER: Well, I mean --

MCDOWELL: I mean participate, rather.

AXLER: Yes, I mean our threshold generally, we see a short interest higher than 30 percent, that's sort of indication to us that hey the market already sees that there's a structural problem here. When the shorts are that high sometimes the cost of borrowing the stock is high.

So we're trying to find situations that aren't crowded where we're actually getting paid right now to short given the general collateral rates of, you know, a percent, percent and-a-half. Those are the situations we want to be involved in.

BARTIROMO: Ok.

BAKER: What's the best short you've done in the last few months?

AXLER: So we shorted Maxar Technologies. That was a merger between McDonald Dettweiler (ph), and a merger between McDonald debt Wyler and digital globe which shorted it in the 50 50s. the stock went down to about $15 a share. They just compare the satellite assets. A lot of debt, no growth. The market is figuring these situations out quickly.

BARTIROMO: So what's your take on the broader market? I know you have specific, you know, shorts in some of the smaller companies that are unknown. But your take on the broader markets? We had a huge rally yesterday. A bit of a pullback this morning.

AXLER: My take is that we're in the later stages of the cycle. I think the market can continue to grind a little bit higher. We've been pretty vocal that we think we're in a sort of low single digit return environment with a lot of volatility. Volatility presents trading opportunities, clearly.

But investors need to play defense. You know, not every stock's a buy. A tremendous amount of the brokers are still putting buy targets and 20 percent upside scenarios on stocks. And that's need to, you know, scrutinize their portfolio carefully, play defense. But they can still make money on the long side. It's just going to be a little harder.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Ben -- it's good to have you. Thanks so much.

AXLER: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Ben Axler joining us and we just showed you the screen of markets pulling back this morning.

We have breaking news we're following this morning, a horrific scene out of California, 12 people are dead. Dozens more are injured after a gunman burst through the doors of a bar on college night.

We're bringing you the very latest from the scene, thousand oaks, California when we come back.

And then summit postponed -- why a second meeting between President Trump and Kim Jong-un may not happen until next year. We've got that news after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good Thursday morning everybody. Welcome back. Thanks very much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, November 8th. We have some sad breaking news to report this morning, at least 12 people are dead after a mass shooting at a bar in California. Among the dead, a sheriff's deputy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GEOFF DEAN, SHERIFF, VENTURA COUNTY, CALIFORNIA: He gave his all and tonight as I told his wife, he died a hero because he went -- he went in to save lives, to save other people.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: A Ventura County Sheriff's spokesman confirmed the gunman is dead as well. 13 people dead that means. We'll have the very latest on the tragedy throughout the morning this morning.

Then, security concerns, Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh will have a scaled back investor -- investiture ceremony today.

Plus, the Pelosi method with the midterms behind us, how President Trump will have to deal with the possible future House speaker. We're dealing with that this morning.

And the sender's remorse, Facebook ready to help if you send a message too soon, details coming up.

Markets are lower today after a powerful rally yesterday. Dow Industrials down about 50 points -- 55 points right now, a quarter of a percent lower. S&P 500 down a third of a percent and the NASDAQ is down almost one half of a percent right now.

Investors are waiting on the Federal Reserve decision that's due at 2:15 p.m. Eastern today. This after a huge day yesterday, Dow Industrials was up 545 points yesterday, better than two percent, following the midterm election news. The major indices all up better than two percent. Look at the NASDAQ up almost 200 points at the close, that was 2.6 percent higher on the NASDAQ.

In Europe this morning no follow up though. Take a look, European indices are mixed. The FT-100 is up 28 points. The CAC Quarante in Paris is flat and the DAX Index in Germany is down 21 points.

Asian markets overnight mixed as well, best performer Japan, Nikkei average up 1.8 percent.

We begin this half an hour with breaking news. We have been following all morning. 12 people have been killed in a mass shooting in a California bar. Among the dead, a sheriff's deputy. Lauren Simonetti with all the details right now, Lauren.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Hi Maria. It is the wee hours of the morning in Thousand Oaks, California, some 40 miles west of Los Angeles. Just hours ago, tragedy unfolded for the families of at least 12 victims. Our local affiliate talking to some of the parents of the students at that Borderline Bar and Grill. They're now trying to get in touch with their sons and daughters. Victims are witnessing the chaos that unfolded.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I was on the like side area, you could say, by the stage and where I was looking was directly of where the guy walked in and started shooting. And, yes, I just -- I can't believe I saw it with my own two eyes. It just freaks me out. Because where I was looking, you know, just by all means some guy just walks in, pulls out a gun and start shooting people. Still just puts me in shock because out here in like Thousand Oaks, just Ventura county area, it's our safe haven. You know, nothing like this happens.

I saw two shots and then I heard about five or six and then that's when I was out of the building. But people I guess there was like smoke -- like grenades going off. I wasn't in the building when that one happened. Everyone was --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: A handgun was found at the scene. No assault rifle. But a search is still being done. Ventura county sheriff Geoff Dean describing the scene earlier this morning.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DEAN: It's a horrific scene in there. There's blood everywhere. And the suspect is part of that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Multiple law enforcement agencies are on the ground. And the Los Angeles Times is reporting that some of the people inside that bar for country night, and you only had to be 18 to get in to line dance, some of those people were also last year in Las Vegas at the mass shooting at the music festival there, Maria.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: That's incredible. And that's what you mentioned earlier, Guy Benson. We'll have more on that coming up. Thank you so much, Lauren.

We want to turn now to the midterm aftermath. Both President Trump and potential House speaker Nancy Pelosi sounding off yesterday about the results and sounding open to reaching across the aisle on certain issues. The Wall Street Journal's editorial board issuing a warning on any potential deal, titled this The Nancy Pelosi Method is an op-ed this morning. Mr. Trump has no fix policy compass on most issues. So there's a serious risk he'll be lured into anti-growth traps. The U.S. could do worse than two years of virtuous gridlock when nothing economically damaging happens in Washington.

Joining us right now is former Hillary for America senior advisor, Democratic strategist, Adrienne Elrod and chairman of the American Conservative Union, Matt Schlapp. Matt, your reaction to the Journal's comments. Thank you so much to you both for joining us this morning.

ADRIENNE ELROD, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Thank you, Maria.

MATT SCHLAPP, CHAIRMAN, AMERICAN CONSERVATIVE UNION: Yes, good to be with you, Maria. I scratch my head when I read Wall Street Journal editorials like this. The president has no policy focus? Come on. We've been watching him in action for two years. He's deregulatory. He believes that taxes should be lowered. You know, his approach to government is when it should do something, it should do it extremely well and extremely efficiently.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

SCHLAPP: But there are plenty of things the government should do. So I think it's a rather absurd editorial. And I'm glad the president is saying that he's going to reach out across the aisle and work with Nancy Pelosi. I'm glad he's saying he's going to think about his tone.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

SCHLAP: And how he approaches things. I applaud everything he is saying.

BARTIROMO: Right, I just think that the editorial is trying to also though make the point, Adrienne, that no agreement is better than a bad agreement. Because if the Dems come in Adrienne and start -- you know, trying to reverse the tax cut plan, reverse the rollback in regulations, that could be damaging to the economy. Your reaction, Adrienne?

ELROD: Yes, well, first of all, I'm glad that President Trump and that leader Pelosi have made it clear that they both want to work together. I think bipartisanship is thoroughly needed right now in this country. And frankly, a lot of independents voted for Democrats in the midterms because they want bipartisanship, but they want cooperation. So, a lot of voters out there in America expect this. I think we'll see compromises on potentially infrastructure and a couple other -- you know, kitchen table issues that matter most to Americans.

I hope Republicans will come to the table on health care and help make some critical fix there's as opposed to repealing health care, Obamacare.

But, you know, look, I think we're off to a good start. Let's hope that this sort of conciliatory approach between both Trump and Pelosi continues.

BENSON: Hi Matt, it's Guy Benson. You said you're applauding everything Trump is saying after the election. But one of the things that he said yesterday was he went down this list of defeated House Republicans from swing districts, tough districts --

SCHLAPP: Yes.

BENSON: -- and named them. You know, Barbara Comstock and Peter Roskam and Carlos Curbelo sort of dancing on their political grave and mocking them for not sort of embracing him or kissing the ring. Is that helpful?

SCHLAPP: Yes, I didn't -- I watched that press conference, Guy. I didn't find him mocking them at all. He was making the point which is there are plenty of reporters who are out there trying to say that this midterms were a bad result for the president. Those of us who work closely in Washington, D.C. for a long time, realize that the House majority wasn't really doing much anyway. I've been really disappointed in the fact that they can't get the number of seats they need in the Senate as well, where it takes 60 for legislations.

So, I think a lot of voters very rationally. Republicans, conservatives and Trump supporters very rationally said it seems like the real action is in the Senate. Let's get these judges confirmed. We're going to probably have another Supreme Court vacancy the next 18 months. This is where we should focus.

Those politicians, Republicans, who are still trying to have their cake and eat it too, they love to diss the president, to be disrespectful. They don't show up at the airport to shake his hand when he comes to their stated district. By the same token they wanted these Trump supporters to be supporting them and the fact is Guy, I think many of these politicians were quite frankly, too political in how they approached this.

Nobody out there in the electorate believes that when you stand up for the president and his policies that are good in your state and in your district and the economy's good almost everywhere in this country, they don't think that you're Donald Trump.

Donald Trump is a very unique guy. And I think they worry that he will hurt them politically. What --actually, what's happening is that they don't get the support of the Trump support because it looks like they're being disrespectful. It was bad politics.

BAKER: Adrienne, this is Gerry Baker with the Wall Street Journal, if I may, the one concern I think the people do have is that the one area where they may be able to find agreement, Democrats in the House and the president, maybe the Senate, is the possibility to spend a lot more money. I mean, when people go to Washington, they get elected, the one thing that everybody can always agree on and I do think again on -- not that I'm defending what the Wall Street Journal editorial board said, but I do think one of the concerns people have about this president is maybe if somebody comes along with a big plan to spend a lot of money, he may find that quite simply.

Now, we already have a fiscal deficit which is going to hit -- you know, trillion dollars, five percent of GDP. That's absolutely the unprecedented this stage of an economic cycle to have a deficit at that large. What's the chances that we just end up seeing the one thing we do in the next couple of years is adding even more to the country's debt?

ELROD: Well, I will tell you this. When I came to Congress when I started working in Washington back in 2002, in Congress, there was something called the Blue Dog Caucus which still does exists. But it's unfortunately a much smaller group of Democrats. But these were Democrats oftentimes from southern states who were very fiscally responsible who wanted to work with Republicans across the aisle to do something about the debt. And so, I think Democrats and Republicans, away that we can really find common ground here is to actually do something about the debt. It's out of control. Building the wall for example would absolutely skyrocket the debt. So, you know, finding approaches where we are being fiscally responsible would be a good thing for both parties to come together on.

MCDOWELL: The wall is not the problem, Adrienne. It is entitlements in this country, largely, where two-thirds of our federal spending is just required --

SCHLAPP: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- by Medicare, Social Security, and the like. Very, very small sliver is discretionary spending in this country.

And Matt Schlapp, to that point, when the Republicans going to get religion on actually cutting spending? Because if you're going to talk about infrastructure spending, how are you going to pay for it? You're going to raise people's gas taxes?

SCHLAPP: Right.

MCDOWELL: People in California just voted to keep the gas tax increase in place that Governor Gerry Brown and the Democrats pushed.

SCHLAPP: Yes, I know Dagen, this is -- your point, I'm going to answer your question with the point you made which is any politician that's not willing to seriously look at entitlements. And look, in all fairness, when President Trump ran for president he said I don't want to -- I don't want to touch these programs. If you don't look at how we bend the curve on these programs, you have absolutely no impact on federal spending.

When you look at the fact that Republicans came in and said we're going to have earmark reform, made most of us laugh because in the end, you're talking about pennies. Pennies out of trillions of dollars, which you really have to look through are, what are the big drivers? And the big drivers are the part of government that's on auto pilot.

BARTIROMO: Right.

SCHLAPP: We can't really do anything to change it. And let me tell you, I think both parties are at fault but Adrienne, I have to push back on this Blue Dog. The Democratic Party has become socialists. They've become so radicalized. I really worry, how can we work with a party that has become so off-the-hook on their political philosophy?

BARTIROMO: Go ahead, Adrienne.

ELROD: I mean, again, Democrats have had no control over the last two years of the House, Senate and the White House. But yet, my friend Matt Schlapp still likes to blame us for a lot of the fiscal issues we have here in this country.

SCHLAPP: We did not have 60 votes in the Senate -- we didn't have 60 votes and you know it.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ELROD: Well, you have a lot more votes now. So, congratulations.

SCHLAPP: Thank God.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much Matt Schlapp, Adrienne ElRod. Good to see you and good issues that we are highlighting there.

President Trump just tweeted on the mass shooting, writing this in part, I have been fully briefed on the terrible shooting in California, law enforcement and first responders together with the FBI are on the scene. 13 people dead at this time have been reported. Likewise, the shooter is dead along with the first police officer to enter the bar. We will bring you more details as this story develops. Stay with us

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back many we are following breaking news this morning. A gunman kills 12 people in California. Cheryl Casone with more details right now, Cheryl.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: We're following everything we can out of California this morning, Maria. This mass shooting happened last night around 11:20 local time in Thousand Oaks, California. That's about 40 miles west of Los Angeles. Now, the bar where this happened was hosting a college country night. It was packed with students at the time of the shooting.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: After the first round it was quiet for about five seconds. And then some guys that were next to me on the floor got up and started sprinting towards the back door and yelled at everyone, get up, run, he's coming. And so it was like 50 people trying to get up and run out the back door all at once.

Unfortunately, I was one of the ones that got caught on the floor and was trampled on by a couple people. On my way up, I got hit in the head by a bar stool being thrown at a window. And I at that moment, I didn't know whether I was going to be able to get up or not and if that guy was really coming, what was going to happen to me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Hundreds of students were in this bar, Maria. A sheriff's deputy was among the 12 victims, Sergeant Ron Helus was the first responder to the scene. He was immediately hit with multiple shots. He is survived by a wife and son. The suspect was also found dead inside that bar.

Another headline we're following for this morning, Maria. President Trump says he thinks that there's going to be a second summit early next year with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. Trump added today's meeting between Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and a senior North Korean official to lay the ground work for the summit is going to be rescheduled.

Now, according to South Korea's Foreign minister, U.S. Officials say North Korea canceled the meeting. There's been little progress on getting North Korea to take steps towards denuclearization since that first Trump-Kim summit happened in June in Singapore.

Well, Facebook's Messenger app is going to give its users a do-over. People who sent a message on the app are now going to have 10 minutes to decide if they want to unsend it. Facebook first began testing the feature last month. Facebook admitted back in April, that they had been quietly deleting messages sent by its CEO, Maria, Mark Zuckerberg.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Well, who didn't want that, right? When you send something and the decided oops, I better unsend it. Who hasn't done that?

BAKER: Does that mean -- does that mean there's a 10 --

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Cheryl.

BAKER: -- essentially a 10 minute delay before you get a message to someone? I mean, supposing --

MCDOWELL: Maybe.

BAKER: You actually want to -- you need to get a message urgently to someone (INAUDIBLE) it's an optional thing, right? --

MCDOWELL: Gerry Baker, you don't use the Facebook Messenger app then.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

BAKER: You don't.

MCDOWELL: You make a phone call like old school.

BAKER: I would like to get a take-back some messages I sent like two years ago.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: OK, we are covering breaking news this morning. It is a terrible story, a deadly mass shooting inside of a California bar on college night, 12 people have been killed including a sheriff's deputy. The gunman is also dead. We have the very latest coming up after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. President Trump just tweeting on the mass shooting this morning. Here's what he said. I have been fully briefed on the terrible shooting in California. Law enforcement and first responders together with the FBI are on the scene. 13 people at this time have been reported dead. Likewise, the shooter is dead along with the first police officer to enter the bar. Great bravery shown by police. California Highway Patrol was on scene within three minutes, with first officer to enter shot numerous times. That sheriff's sergeant died in the hospital. God bless all of the victims and families of the victims. Thank you to law enforcement. Writes the president this morning.

Meanwhile, Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh will have a scaled back investiture ceremony today. Fox News Doug McKelway has more. He's at the White House this morning. Doug, good morning to you.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DOUG MCKELWAY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning Maria, and it's going to be a slightly scaled down investiture because of security concerns here in the nation's capital. The traditional walk that most new justices take down the front steps of the Supreme Court building will not happen today out of those security concerns. It also comes at a time when the controversy over Justice Kavanaugh is not dying down at all here in Washington. Listen to what Mitch McConnell said yesterday about the Kavanaugh effect on increasing the Senate -- GOP majority. Here he is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MITCH MCCONNELL (R-KY), SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: I think it was like an adrenaline shot. We were worried about lack of intensity on our side and I think the Kavanaugh fight certainly provided that. It was extremely helpful. It's noteworthy that the one Democrat in a red state who survived voted for Kavanaugh, Joe Manchin.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCKELWAY: Meanwhile, Democrats may not let up on Kavanaugh. We understand from a report by Mollie Hemingway in the federalist that she overheard the soon to be chairman of the House Judiciary Committee Jerrold Nadler suggest on a telephone call yesterday that they're going to begin impeachment proceedings against the new Supreme Court Justice. Back to you, Maria.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: All right, Doug thank you so much. Doug McKelway is at the White House this morning.

Breaking news overnight, a deadly mass shooting in California, a dozen people are dead including a sheriff's deputy after a gunman burst into a college bar. Next hour, MORNINGS WITH MARIA, we've got the very latest. We will go back live. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, good Thursday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, November 8th. Your top stories right now just before 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

We have breaking news that we have been covering, there has been a mass shooting in a California bar, at least 12 people were killed including a sheriff's deputy. The gunman also dead, Ventura county sheriff describing the scene inside that bar. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DEAN: It's a horrific scene in there. There's blood everywhere. And the suspect is part of that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have the very latest. Coming up, the developments as they come in.

Plus, Jeff Sessions was fired.

A year-and-a-half ago, legal and compliance staff at companies across Europe were grumbling at the mad scramble to prepare for new EU privacy laws.

Now, the same rush has fallen on US companies struggling to digest and implement privacy rules that will come into force in California from January 1.

Initially passed last year, the California Consumer Privacy Act, or CCPA, gives Californian consumers the right to see all the personal information a business holds about them and ask for that data to be deleted or not sold on to third parties. 

Designed mainly to curb the data practices of deep-pocketed tech giants such as Google and Facebook, whose business models rely on wielding user information to target advertising, the rules will actually impact an estimated 500,000 companies operating across the US, from financial and professional services groups to smaller online retailers. 

After fierce lobbying to water it down, and a slew of amendments, the bill reached a final draft this month, leaving companies little time to plan for when it takes effect. Many have complained that the bill is both confusing and likely to hit them with hefty compliance costs.

“Businesses have been waiting, waiting, waiting to see how these amendments come out and this only really leaves a few weeks now [to prepare],” said Rafi Azim-Khan, partner and head of privacy team at Pillsbury Law. “Whether they get everything done and everything right — that’s going to be an open question.”

The CCPA applies to any company with at least $25m in annual gross revenues that does business in California, or collects and processes data on California residents — even if they do not have a physical presence in the state.

In addition, businesses that buy or sell the data of more than 50,000 California consumers, or derive 50 per cent of their annual revenues from selling their data, are subject to the rules. 

The shake-up is part of a move to protect individual privacy rights in response to high-profile data protection scandals such as Facebook’s Cambridge Analytica debacle, and major customer data breaches at Equifax and Capital One. 

Though considered less burdensome than Europe’s general data protection regulation (GDPR), which came into force in May 2018, experts say the CCPA is likely to set the standard for privacy across the US, after efforts by big tech firms to urge Congress to introduce a softer, more sweeping national bill fell flat. 

In preparation, the California regulator has been bolstering its resources; it was granted $4.7m in funding and 23 new hires, including several enforcement attorneys, in the 2019-2020 fiscal year from the Department of Finance, specifically to implement the new rules.

“Once the new law takes effect, the California attorney-general will overnight become one of the most powerful privacy regulators in the world,” said Lindsey Tonsager, partner at global law firm Covington. 

If consumers decided to stop their data from being collected or sold — businesses are expected to put an “opt out” button on the homepage of their website — it could cause ripples through the online marketing industry and hurt sales at those which make the bulk of their money through customised advertising.

But experts said the bigger worry for businesses was the cost of compliance.

A March survey of 250 US privacy professionals, conducted by compliance technology company Trustarc, found that nearly four in 10 expect to spend at least $500,000 adhering to the rules, while for close to a fifth, that figure is more than $1m. 

Smaller businesses with fewer resources will bear the brunt, since global companies such as Google and Facebook may already have the required systems in place, after adopting the EU standards, known as GDPR, as their default.

“Companies that already had to apply to the EU GDPR are ahead of the curve,” said Ms Tonsager. “Smaller and medium businesses are having to spend — millions of dollars in some cases — to comply,” she said, adding that these costs could be “indirectly passed through to consumers”. 

Above all, many will be investing in ways to update legacy systems to field users’ requests to see their data within 45 days, and to ensure they can verify the identity of users without having to collect even more information on them. 

They must also weigh whether to attempt the tricky process of carving out the personal information of California residents from other US users, or simply roll out the changes they make across the country.

Even assessing which types of information fall under the scope of the rules in the first instance has proven challenging, according to Whitney Merrill, privacy and data counsel at San Francisco-based Brex, which offers corporate cards to start-ups.

“We have been making sure that we have a firm understanding of the law,” Ms Merrill said. “Especially since — I’ll be frank — it was very quickly written, and any privacy advocate would tell you it’s poorly written.”

According to data published by eMarketer, only 42 per cent of 1,500 US businesses surveyed in July this year were prepared or expected to be prepared by the deadline; the remainder either expected to miss the deadline or were making no preparations at all. 

But the cost of falling short of the rules is high. The California attorney-general can seek as much as $7,500 per person for any general breach of the rules, if it is intentional. But in the case of a hack, individual citizens can sue for as much as $750 each even if no damage was caused, or actual damages, whichever is greater. 

“There’s a heavy price to pay if you’re on the wrong side of the regulations,” said Elizabeth Gallagher, chief revenue officer at software development company Lineate. “This will affect your reputation as well as your bottom line”. 

Companies operating in Europe have already felt the pain under GDPR; this year, British Airways was hit with a £183m fine for failing to comply with the rules while Google suffered a  €50m fine.  Unsurprisingly, as in Europe, a brisk market of start-ups is springing up with the promise of providing software solutions to aid compliance. 

“It’s hitting [businesses] like a tonne of bricks right now,” said Dominic Sartorio, senior vice-president of product and development at cloud security group Protegrity. “That realisation is setting in.”

urn:contentItem:6047-4DN1-JCBW-N0YJ-00000-00Californians eye an easier life after virus2020-06-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:21ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 14,15Californians eye an easier life after virusBen Hoyle

Even though he grew up in Missouri, Jack Dorsey is the most earnestly Californian of Big Tech moguls: a fan of ice baths and cryptocurrency, of fasting, drinking salt juice and silent meditation retreats.

So when the coronavirus swept in, the co-founder and chief executive of Twitter seized on the disruption as a chance to experiment. After two months of lockdown he emailed his employees to say that they could stay away from the office and keep working from home if they wanted. For ever.

California has always had an outsized presence in the American imagination, amplified by its image as the place where the futures of work, leisure, transport and communities are dreamt up. Hollywood and Silicon Valley give it enormous global reach.The mayor of Los Angeles, Eric Garcetti, crystallised the moment of flux thrown up by Covid-19 when he said in April: "Is normal really what we want to come back to?" Many Californians have a one-word answer and have been busy planning for a more idealistic future, with plans to empty prisons, slash homelessness, improve internet access for poorer households and boost voter turnout.

Some big changes have already happened. About 3,500 inmates have been released from state prisons since February due to fears of a coronavirus outbreak and a need to cut costs. "I don't see us going back to the old days," said George Gascón, a former San Francisco police chief now running to be district attorney in Los Angeles who has campaigned against mass incarceration. "Crime hasn't gone up."

He added: "There are going to be conversations that were viewed as radically left a few months ago that are not going to be that way any more."

Other seemingly intractable social problems have been put in reverse. Project Roomkey, an effort to move the most vulnerable of California's 150,000 homeless people off the streets, has found shelter for thousands in empty hotels, motels and other spaces.

"It happened more immediately than anything I could have imagined before, with a sense of urgency that we needed a long time ago but finally came because of Covid-19," Andy Bales, who runs the Union Rescue Mission in Skid Row, downtown Los Angeles, said.

However, he added: "I don't believe there's been an upgrade in overall infrastructure yet to make the changes last." Nowhere in America is more associated with vast wealth or left-wing thinking than California. At the same time it has the worst poverty rate of any American state by some measures.

Technology companies have donated hundreds of thousands of free wifi connections and tens of thousands of devices to help disadvantaged pupils learn at home during the lockdown. But state politicians believe they can increase pressure on internet providers to do more for the 1.2 million children who lack a device or high-speed connection to benefit from remote learning.

California may be trying to lead the way out of the pandemic. It also led the country into the outbreak. Patricia Dowd, a 57-year-old auditor, dropped dead in her kitchen in San Jose on February 6 after developing flu-like symptoms. In April tissue samples confirmed that she had coronavirus, making her America's earliest known victim.

Since her death state officials have been largely effective in managing the pandemic by tackling it early and decisively and by emphasising science over politics. The state's 4,900 deaths are only a few hundred more than the toll in Connecticut, which has less than a tenth as many people. The governor, Gavin Newsom, has seen his approval rating increase from 53 per cent in February to 65 per cent in a poll last week. Democratic activists and politicians have pressed for years for an expansion of postal voting to make democracy more accessible. Some Republicans, including President Trump, have complained without substantial evidence that it encourages electoral fraud.

Mr Newsom, 52, has seized the moment, ordering counties to post a ballot for November's presidential election to all voters to protect public health and voting rights.

A new Great Depression stands to cost California as much as any other state, if not more. Its population of roughly 40 million is bigger than that of Canada, Australia or Poland. If it were an independent nation it would be the fifth largest economy in the world.

By early May, 24 per cent of workers in Los Angeles were out of employment, roughly equal to peak joblessness in the 1930s. The latest figures show statewide unemployment was at 15.5 per cent in April. However, technology jobs in San Francisco and in Santa Clara county, which largely overlaps with Silicon Valley, fell by only 3 to 4 per cent. This resilience is likely to lead the state economy out of the pandemic - for good and ill.

Big Tech was on the rack before coronavirus arrived. The justice department was reviewing "market-leading platforms". Congress was pressing for tougher regulation and some Democratic presidential candidates were calling for companies such as Amazon and Facebook to be broken up. Now those companies are enjoying a rise in public trust and governments have leaned on their support for contact tracing.

The industry is already reimagining their workplaces in America and beyond. Facebook and Google have followed Twitter in saying that they are exploring moves for employees to work from home, albeit less ambitious ones.

These companies have already transchina formed the world of white-collar work many times, according to Margaret O'Mara, a history professor at the University of Washington. They altered "the ideal of what a business leader looks like" and expectations of what an aspirational office environment should be, she said, with "ping-pong tables, climbing walls and free food". The pandemic has provided an unexpected opportunity for another reassessment, a "giant real-time experiment in working from home".

The impact on workers would be uncertain. Employers could pay less to people in rural Montana than in San Francisco. The pre-pandemic Silicon Valley also contributed heavily to the global erosion of work-life balance. "How do you create a work culture that allows people to turn off, even if they're physically working and living in the same space?" asked Dr O'Mara. Solving that "would be a useful problem for the tech companies to set themselves".

Twenty years ago an upstart search engine company supercharged its growth by snapping up cheap jobless engineers and second-hand computers in the aftermath of the dotcom bust. In 2003 it moved into the vast headquarters that become known as the Googleplex. Last month Sundar Pichai, Google's chief executive, offered every one of the parent company's almost 120,000 global staff a sweetener to help with the next few months: $1,000 each to spend on their home offices.

Three cases emerge in Beijing after 55-day break Beijing has reported three new cases of coronavirus, raising concerns over a possible outbreak in the capital after a 55-day streak of no infection was broken on Thursday.

The authorities yesterday said a 25-year-old man who works for the China Meat Research Centre had tested positive. One of his colleagues, a 37-year-old man, also developed symptoms and tested positive. The news comes a day after the city reported a 52-year-old man was diagnosed with the virus.

somalia Al-Shabaab, an extremist group linked to Al-Qaeda, has unveiled a Covid-19 care facility in Jilib, a stronghold in southern Somalia, and set up a 24-hour hotline saying treatment would be offered to "all people". Sheikh Mohamed Bali, an al-Shabaab official, urged people with symptoms "to come to the medical facility and avoid infecting other Muslims".

italy Luca Zaia, the governor of Italy's northern Veneto region, is appealing to British tourists to return as he reopens opera venues following a successful track and trace campaign against the coronavirus. Every other seat at the venues will be left empty. Yesterday, no new cases were registered in the region.

europe Poland and Sweden are the only EU countries to have not yet passed their Covid-19 peak, the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control said. The virus's 14-day incidence "was at the highest level yet observed" in the two countries, it added.

russia President Putin took part in a flag-raising ceremony in Moscow in only his second public appearance since late March. Neither Mr Putin, 67, nor the majority present wore masks. Mr Putin embraced guests and shook hands.

ukraine Olena Zelenska, Ukraine's first lady, has tested positive for the coronavirus amid a rise in infections as the country eases lockdown restrictions. Ms Zelenska, 42, said she is selfisolating and that her husband, President Zelensky, and their two children tested negative.

australia Crowds of up 10,000 people will be allowed into sports stadiums with a capacity of 40,000 or under from next month, Scott Morrison, the prime minister, has said as Covid-19 restrictions are further relaxed. All patrons must be seated according to social distancing rules.

new zealand A cyberattack has led the Lion brewery, which produces popular brands such as Speights and Lion Red, to shut down just as pubs and restaurants across New Zealand were fully reopened.

urn:contentItem:6047-4DN1-JCBW-N0GC-00000-00Californians eye an easier life after virus2020-06-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:21ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 16,17Californians eye an easier life after virusBen Hoyle

Even though he grew up in Missouri, Jack Dorsey is the most earnestly Californian of Big Tech moguls: a fan of ice baths and cryptocurrency, of fasting, drinking salt juice and silent meditation retreats.

So when the coronavirus swept in, the co-founder and chief executive of Twitter seized on the disruption as a chance to experiment. After two months of lockdown he emailed his employees to say that they could stay away from the office and keep working from home if they wanted. For ever.

California has always had an outsized presence in the American imagination, amplified by its image as the place where the futures of work, leisure, transport and communities are dreamt up. Hollywood and Silicon Valley give it enormous global reach.The mayor of Los Angeles, Eric Garcetti, crystallised the moment of flux thrown up by Covid-19 when he said in April: "Is normal really what we want to come back to?" Many Californians have a one-word answer and have been busy planning for a more idealistic future, with plans to empty prisons, slash homelessness, improve internet access for poorer households and boost voter turnout.

Some big changes have already happened. About 3,500 inmates have been released from state prisons since February due to fears of a coronavirus outbreak and a need to cut costs. "I don't see us going back to the old days," said George Gascón, a former San Francisco police chief now running to be district attorney in Los Angeles who has campaigned against mass incarceration. "Crime hasn't gone up."

He added: "There are going to be conversations that were viewed as radically left a few months ago that are not going to be that way any more."

Other seemingly intractable social problems have been put in reverse. Project Roomkey, an effort to move the most vulnerable of California's 150,000 homeless people off the streets, has found shelter for thousands in empty hotels, motels and other spaces.

"It happened more immediately than anything I could have imagined before, with a sense of urgency that we needed a long time ago but finally came because of Covid-19," Andy Bales, who runs the Union Rescue Mission in Skid Row, downtown Los Angeles, said.

However, he added: "I don't believe there's been an upgrade in overall infrastructure yet to make the changes last." Nowhere in America is more associated with vast wealth or left-wing thinking than California. At the same time it has the worst poverty rate of any American state by some measures.

Technology companies have donated hundreds of thousands of free wifi connections and tens of thousands of devices to help disadvantaged pupils learn at home during the lockdown. But state politicians believe they can increase pressure on internet providers to do more for the 1.2 million children who lack a device or high-speed connection to benefit from remote learning.

California may be trying to lead the way out of the pandemic. It also led the country into the outbreak. Patricia Dowd, a 57-year-old auditor, dropped dead in her kitchen in San Jose on February 6 after developing flu-like symptoms. In April tissue samples confirmed that she had coronavirus, making her America's earliest known victim.

Since her death state officials have been largely effective in managing the pandemic by tackling it early and decisively and by emphasising science over politics. The state's 4,900 deaths are only a few hundred more than the toll in Connecticut, which has less than a tenth as many people. The governor, Gavin Newsom, has seen his approval rating increase from 53 per cent in February to 65 per cent in a poll last week. Democratic activists and politicians have pressed for years for an expansion of postal voting to make democracy more accessible. Some Republicans, including President Trump, have complained without substantial evidence that it encourages electoral fraud.

Mr Newsom, 52, has seized the moment, ordering counties to post a ballot for November's presidential election to all voters to protect public health and voting rights.

A new Great Depression stands to cost California as much as any other state, if not more. Its population of roughly 40 million is bigger than that of Canada, Australia or Poland. If it were an independent nation it would be the fifth largest economy in the world.

By early May, 24 per cent of workers in Los Angeles were out of employment, roughly equal to peak joblessness in the 1930s. The latest figures show statewide unemployment was at 15.5 per cent in April. However, technology jobs in San Francisco and in Santa Clara county, which largely overlaps with Silicon Valley, fell by only 3 to 4 per cent. This resilience is likely to lead the state economy out of the pandemic - for good and ill.

Big Tech was on the rack before coronavirus arrived. The justice department was reviewing "market-leading platforms". Congress was pressing for tougher regulation and some Democratic presidential candidates were calling for companies such as Amazon and Facebook to be broken up. Now those companies are enjoying a rise in public trust and governments have leaned on their support for contact tracing.

The industry is already reimagining their workplaces in America and beyond. Facebook and Google have followed Twitter in saying that they are exploring moves for employees to work from home, albeit less ambitious ones.

These companies have already transchina formed the world of white-collar work many times, according to Margaret O'Mara, a history professor at the University of Washington. They altered "the ideal of what a business leader looks like" and expectations of what an aspirational office environment should be, she said, with "ping-pong tables, climbing walls and free food". The pandemic has provided an unexpected opportunity for another reassessment, a "giant real-time experiment in working from home".

The impact on workers would be uncertain. Employers could pay less to people in rural Montana than in San Francisco. The pre-pandemic Silicon Valley also contributed heavily to the global erosion of work-life balance. "How do you create a work culture that allows people to turn off, even if they're physically working and living in the same space?" asked Dr O'Mara. Solving that "would be a useful problem for the tech companies to set themselves".

Twenty years ago an upstart search engine company supercharged its growth by snapping up cheap jobless engineers and second-hand computers in the aftermath of the dotcom bust. In 2003 it moved into the vast headquarters that become known as the Googleplex. Last month Sundar Pichai, Google's chief executive, offered every one of the parent company's almost 120,000 global staff a sweetener to help with the next few months: $1,000 each to spend on their home offices.

Three cases emerge in Beijing after 55-day break Beijing has reported three new cases of coronavirus, raising concerns over a possible outbreak in the capital after a 55-day streak of no infection was broken on Thursday.

The authorities yesterday said a 25-year-old man who works for the China Meat Research Centre had tested positive. One of his colleagues, a 37-year-old man, also developed symptoms and tested positive. The news comes a day after the city reported a 52-year-old man was diagnosed with the virus.

somalia Al-Shabaab, an extremist group linked to Al-Qaeda, has unveiled a Covid-19 care facility in Jilib, a stronghold in southern Somalia, and set up a 24-hour hotline saying treatment would be offered to "all people". Sheikh Mohamed Bali, an al-Shabaab official, urged people with symptoms "to come to the medical facility and avoid infecting other Muslims".

italy Luca Zaia, the governor of Italy's northern Veneto region, is appealing to British tourists to return as he reopens opera venues following a successful track and trace campaign against the coronavirus. Every other seat at the venues will be left empty. Yesterday, no new cases were registered in the region.

europe Poland and Sweden are the only EU countries to have not yet passed their Covid-19 peak, the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control said. The virus's 14-day incidence "was at the highest level yet observed" in the two countries, it added.

russia President Putin took part in a flag-raising ceremony in Moscow in only his second public appearance since late March. Neither Mr Putin, 67, nor the majority present wore masks. Mr Putin embraced guests and shook hands.

ukraine Olena Zelenska, Ukraine's first lady, has tested positive for the coronavirus amid a rise in infections as the country eases lockdown restrictions. Ms Zelenska, 42, said she is selfisolating and that her husband, President Zelensky, and their two children tested negative.

australia Crowds of up 10,000 people will be allowed into sports stadiums with a capacity of 40,000 or under from next month, Scott Morrison, the prime minister, has said as Covid-19 restrictions are further relaxed. All patrons must be seated according to social distancing rules.

new zealand A cyberattack has led the Lion brewery, which produces popular brands such as Speights and Lion Red, to shut down just as pubs and restaurants across New Zealand were fully reopened.

California, with 40 million people, is aiming to lead America out of the pandemicA waiter takes orders on St Mark's Square in Venice, while in Amsterdam Kira Hilli, a ballerina, heads out in a "social distance tutu" with a 3-metre diameter

urn:contentItem:5RMV-KHX1-F03R-N0V5-00000-00Californians trust tech companies but want regulations to rein them in2018-02-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:21ZLexisNexisCalifornians trust tech companies but want regulations to rein them inDean Takahashi

Feb 13, 2018( VentureBeat: http://venturebeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) The tech industry is the most-trusted sector in California, but two-thirds of residents in the Bay Area — home of Silicon Valley — think it has been underregulated, according to a survey by public relations firm Edelman. There's an apparent paradox between trust in the tech industry and a desire for more regulation as thorny issues such as privacy become increasingly important. The survey is meant to gauge the mood of the nation's most populous state when it comes to tech, government, the economy, and the workplace.

For the 2018 Edelman Trust Barometer[1], the firm interviewed 1,502 people living in California. The group interviewed 500 people in the Bay Area and 500 in Los Angeles, with the rest coming from other parts of the state. Edelman also surveyed more than 33,000 people across the nation. A few highlights? More than 70 percent of California women believe core local industries have not done enough for gender quality at work. And more than seven in 10 Californians believe that industry can and should advocate for societal good. Looking specifically at the tech industry, 79 percentof Californians (83 percent of Bay Area residents and 77 percent of LA area residents) believetech companies have an obligation to speak out against policies that may hurt their employeesor customers, yet 66 percent say the tech industry is reactive, rather than proactive. Above: Californians know the big tech firms but aren't as familiar with social media companies. Image Credit: EdelmanWithin the Bay Area, 62 percent of those surveyed say they trust the tech industry,yet only 38 percent believe the growth of technology hasbenefited them personally, underscoring the potential for the public to turn on the techindustry. In fact, 62 percent of Bay Area residents say 'the tech industry makes the wealthyeven wealthier, but doesn't really help the rest of California.' More than two-thirds of Bay Area residents (67 percent) think the tech industry has been giventoo much freedom and needs more regulation. According to Bay Area respondents, theseregulations should include making tech companies more financially liable for data breaches (89percent support), taxing companies that move their manufacturing overseas (82 percent),taxing companies that replace workers with machines (66 percent), reducing the number ofskilled workers from abroad (66 percent) and preventing tech monopolies (56 percent). 'In the battle to protect its license to innovate around the world, the industry must first dealwith perception at home. All politics is local,' said Kristine Boyden, president of Edelman'sWestern Region, in a statement. The survey also found that the public distrusts social media. While 62percent of Californians trust the tech industry overall, just 37 percent said they trust social media companies. In the Bay Area, social media is even less trusted, with roughly a third(35 percent) of residents saying they trust the industry, making it the least-trusted industry thatEdelmantested. When it comes to what companies comprise the techindustry, Apple is the top company that comes to mind, followed by Google, Microsoft,and Samsung, with social media companies lagging far behind. More than 77 percent of Californians blame social media for the problem of fakenews, and by a 58- to 42-point margin (61 to 39 in the Bay Area) Californians maintain thatsocial media spreads misinformation rather than helping people become more informed about issues. It's therefore not surprising that more than seven in 10 support a variety ofregulations, including 86 percent supporting requirements of the same standards for politicalads on social media as on TV, 78 percent supporting fines on social media companies that host,publicize, or repeat fake news, 75 percent supporting fines against social media companies whenpeople use their platforms to violate the law, and 74 percent supporting a requirement thatsocial media companies review all content posted on their platform for accuracy. Above: Map of Silicon Valley Image Credit: ShutterstockMore than 70 percent of Californiawomen believe the media, entertainment, and technology industries have not done enough toimprove gender equality and fair treatment in the workplace. One-third of California women(32 percent) reported that they had been sexually harassed at work, with 38 percent havingexperienced unfair treatment at work because of their gender. That number goes upsignificantly for Bay Area women (46 percent) and California's college-educated women (49percent). Sixty-five percent of respondents said that women in positions ofpower are more trustworthy than men, a seven-percentage point increase since 2017. The perception that women in power are more truthful thanmen holds across both genders, with 52 percent of men and 77 percent of women citing femaleleaders as more trustworthy. That's not a surprise, given the #MeToo[2] movement and the steady stream of harassment scandals coming out of Silicon Valley. 'Clear actions, grounded in well-articulated values, are a must for companies to build trust fromthe inside out. Beginning with their own employees, then shifting toward the communities inwhich they work and into society at large, there is both expectation and opportunity forbusiness to lead,' said Stacey Zolt Hara, managing director of corporate and public affairs forEdelman Bay Area, in a statement. Above: Social media isn't trusted as much as tech as a whole in California. Image Credit: EdelmanHousing costs remain a huge issue, with 71 percent of Californians (77 percent Bay Area, 70 percent Los Angeles) reporting that the costand availability of housing is a 'very serious' concern. This group far outpaces the 43 percent whoconsider the lack of high-paying jobs a very serious concern. More than half of Californians (57 percent) said they don't believe their children will have a better life than they do. Andbecause of the high cost of living, Edelman found that there has been an increase amongmillennials (58 percent) and parents (65 percent) who are considering leaving California, up seven and 12 percentage points respectively in the last year. Interviews were conducted online from January 12 to January 22. [ 1]: https://www.edelman.com/trust-barometer [ 2]:   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Me_Too_movement
