Jun 29, 2018( The Independent View: http://ipview.blospot.com Delivered by Newstex) California enacted the Nation's Strongest Data Privacy Law on Thursday that could create National Changes to how Big Tech Companies, including Facebook, Google, and Amazon, Collect and Use Personal Data.The Law, Passed by the State Legislature on Tuesday and Signed by Gov. Jerry Brown, requires Companies to Disclose the Types of Data they Collect about Consumers and with Whom they Share that Information. Companies will be Forced to Let Consumers Opt-Out of having their Data Sold.The Law will also Prohibit Companies from Charging a Consumer or Treating them Differently because they Opted-Out of having their Data Sold.

Companies will also be Required to Secure Customer Data or Risk being Fined by California's Attorney General, according to the Legislation.The Protections won't take effect until 2020, meaning the Fight between Lawmakers, Advocates, and Tech Companies to further Shape the Regulations, or Water them Down, is still far from over.California's New Privacy Protections have been heralded as the Strongest Consumer Privacy Measure in Decades and are part of a growing Movement to give People more Control over their Data. While the spirit of the Law is similar to Europe's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which went into effect last month, it doesn't go as far as GDPR, which is now considered the Strongest Data Privacy Law in the World. In response to GDPR, which took effect last month, many Large Tech Companies, even those based in the U.S., Revamped their Privacy Policies and Created Tools to give Users more Control over the Types of Data that is Collected.James Steyer, Founder and CEO of Nonprofit Tech Watchdog Common Sense, said the Passage of the Bill is a "huge victory" but isn't perfect. "I would like to see even more aspects of privacy opt-in versus opt-out, but this is a huge improvement," Steyer said.The vote wasn't without a bit of last-minute drama. Lawmakers had until Thursday afternoon to Pass the Bill, entitled the California Consumer Privacy Act of 2018. If they did, Alastair Mactaggart, a Wealthy Real Estate Developer, said he would pull an even Tougher Measure that had Secured a Spot on the State's November Ballot. Mactaggart's Californians for Consumer Privacy Bill would give Consumers even more Power over their data, such as the Ability to Sue Companies that may have Mishandled their Privacy and Security.The Internet Association, the Lobbying Force representing many Large Technology Companies, had expressed its Disapproval for the Ballot Measure. Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook's Chief Operating Officer, told Reporters at an Event held at Facebook Headquarters on Thursday Morning that the Social Network supported the Legislative Action.Once Signed, the Bill will provide in 2020, California Residents with the Strongest Consumer Privacy Protections in the United States. It is also expected to have Wide-Ranging Implications for Everyone in the United States.Privacy Rights Activists have said they believe the Next Steps could be Instituting Stronger Privacy Protections at the Federal Level.Regardless of whether Congress Acts, Steyer said California's law will have a ripple effect and be a positive for all Americans. "California's law will become the law of the land," he said. "Waiting for Congress and this current executive breach to be functional is like a joke."NYC Wins When Everyone Can Vote! Michael H. LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: -- this after a rollercoaster. Volatile day yesterday for the stock market. The Dow swinging from high to low more than 850 points, finishing up more than 260 points. The S&P tacking on about a percent yesterday and the NASDAQ about a third of one percent.

The Council of Economic Advisers Chairman Kevin Hassett saying the President is happy with economy going into the end of the year.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEVIN HASSETT, CHAIRMAN, COUNCIL OF ECONOMIC ADVISERS: I think the President thinks that the economy the -- is doing well that the economic fundamentals are sound and I think he is very pleased to see that the markets are moving back to sort of where they belong given the fundamentals.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: So investors are building on yesterday's rally today in the U.S. And Europe is rallying also. The FTSE in London is up 133 points, that is now two percent. So we are grinding higher as the morning goes on. Asian markets mostly higher overnight. The Nikkei down a third of one percent. The only one in the red. It is day seven of the government shutdown and it does not look like it will end before the New Year. We're going to break it all down for you.

And then it's deadline day for Sears. The struggling retailer has until the end of today to find a bidder for its assets or it could disappear entirely.

Plus, the fight for higher wages. Up to 22 states including New York, Maine, and Oregon set to raise their minimum wage in 2019. The fallout for business as a result, that's coming up.

And will the real Alexa -- please stand up? A fake Alexa app topping the charts in the app store. You won't believe it. You could be vulnerable. Here with me to break it all down, Fox News Contributor, "GREG GUTFELD SHOW" correspondent, National Review reporter Kat Timpf; Beyond Sport Global Ambassador and Fox News Contributor, John Layfield; and former state department spokesperson and co-host of "BENSON & HARF" on Fox News Radio, Marie Harf. All right. Good morning guys.

MARIE HARF, FOX NEWS RADIO HOST: Good morning.

SIMONETTI: Final hour here.

HARF: One more hour left.

SIMONETTI: How do you feel?

HARF: Oh, I feel great. I feel great, yes. It's get to get an early start, you know. Be up at 3:30 in the morning. It's everyone's favorite thing.

SIMONETTI: And you just flew in last night.

HARF: I just flew in last night, yes. Absolutely. But I was in bed by 8:30. So, it's good.

SIMONETTI: Good girl. Good girl. Bringing the energy this morning. Also joining the conversation, the former CKE Restaurant CEO as well as former labor secretary nominee, Andy Puzder, and Texas Congressman Michael Burgess. So, you don't want to miss a beat. Let's get straight to our top story this hour and that is Wall Street's wild week. Futures set to open higher this morning.

Of course this is not how we close but it's how we're opening on the heels of another volatile trading day. This has become the new norm. The Dow did stage a comeback, it was late yesterday. In fact it was a record-swing of almost 900 points wrapping up this volatile week for the markets. Let's bring in Kingsview Asset Management CIO Scott Martin to try to make sense of all of it. What do you think, Scott?

SCOTT MARTIN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Let's make some sense of it, Lauren. At least try. Here's the thing. You know, here's what's good that's happening right now is that the markets are starting to heal I believe. I mean, Monday was an absolutes destructive day as I've said over the last few weeks and gotten some ribbing for it mind you is if this is a barf bottom type of day, Monday was certainly going into Christmas it really tried ruin everybody's holidays.

And now we're seeing this market really recover nicely. In fact yesterday, you know, when we had a big sell-off, it looked like it was going to break again, it didn't, it came back. Now, the only thing that I'll tell you that's still kind of hanging out there is we need to see some volume come back because volume has been way more prevalent on the down days than it has the up days. So, some conviction buying is I think the next leg up here.

SIMONETTI: And what do you make of gold rallying?

MARTIN: We love gold. We own gold. I kind of feel like gold member here by saying I love gold, you know, like the movie. But the reality is true though because gold right now unlike say your bonds which just have been rallying back as interest rates have come down but certainly unlike your stocks have really been that low volatility kind of just get me over the hump trade. And so, right now with U.S. dollar in our opinion kind of maybe peaking out, intending to trend lower here in the 2019, I think gold is a great addition to your portfolio.

If you're looking for something other than say just traditional stocks and bonds.

JOHN LAYFIELD, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Scott, how you doing? Congratulations to Chicago Bears, I think your defense out there is the best I've seen since the 86 Bears. But I want to ask you -- I want to ask you about gold, you know, you get in gold as you say is safe haven and most people that get into gold are worried about what's going on in markets. You mentioned healing, it doesn't seem like much has changed. We still have all this unpredictability. Are you bullish going forward?

MARTIN: Yes. We are bullish here, John, but I think, you know, the interesting thing you have to think about is near term, this volatility is going to stick around. You made a good point. It's not like any of the stuff just because we because we rally, you know what, about 15 points on the Dow, it's going to go away. You know, these concerns over the trade wars, these concerns over the Fed's involvement frankly concerns we have that economic data is possibly slowing.

There's probably going to be some earnings compression. So, you're right, you know, it's not like just a few days kind of -- kind of cure these ills but the reality is this is starting the process of some market healing to wear. If you got that long-term time horizon say, you know, couple of years, three years in advance, these are great buying opportunities. I will throw into, John, that Bears defense is missing somebody like you one that I think because they're going to get beaten in the playoffs.

And I like the Minnesota Vikings anyway, so I'm getting crushed here.

SIMONETTI: Scott --

LAYFIELD: Yes. You had your reign on the Bears, I forgot you're a Vikings fan. Yes. You live in Chicago.

(CROSSTALK)

HARF: He's wearing a purple tie.

MARTIN: See that? You got it.

HARF: We all know the real football is played on Saturdays in college football, we were talking about that earlier. Scott --

MARTIN: Ohio State -- yes.

HARF: Yes, exactly. I'm a huge Buckeye fan, Scott. So thank you for bringing that up. I will watch the Rose Bowl. Let's turn to 2019 in IPOs. Could be a record year. We're looking at companies like Uber, Palantir, others, possibly accelerating towards earlier in year. What's your prediction for what IPOs might look like?

MARTIN: Yes. You know, Maria, IPOs are good sign of a -- of a good economy, a good market because think about it, you know, you and I have a private lemonade stand if you will, you know, outside of Columbus, Ohio which I'm form the other side of Columbus, I know you're from the east side, I'm from the west side of Columbus.

HARF: Hey.

MARTIN: Like if we had a lemonade stand that was private -- that's right, Clark County, Ohio. Here's the thing though. If we had a private lemonade stand that we want to take public per se, we would do that in the market environment where we thought we could get a good price appreciation or get investors, get interest as far as capital. And so it's a good sign that companies are looking to come to market.

However, I think what we've learned from the IPO market is that it's a dicey game. You know, look at -- look at companies that we probably all use like Spotify, look at Blue Apron, you know, trading under a dollar now (INAUDIBLE) was the one that got destroyed that I really liked for a long time. There's just areas in the market that sometimes overinflate. So, if you're an individual investor sometimes the IPO if you're a public investor is too late to get in.

SIMONETTI: What about mergers and acquisitions, do you expect to see a lot of M&A? And I'm asking in the context of some companies maybe in healthcare or other sectors are more powerful together and they can weather the pending storm if you will, together, but other companies and we're seeing that with general electric and united technologies, they're segmenting into different businesses. Which way do you see going in 2019?

MARTIN: Yes. It's going to be funny. There's going to be like two kinds I think, Lauren. There's going to be ones that are M&A out of absolute desperation, right? You know, companies that need to combine to kind of stay alive or there's other ones that are going to be opportunistic. But I tell you the best two areas probably for mergers and acquisitions going forward is probably healthcare as you mentioned and certainly technology.

Because here's the best part about the sell-off so far. A lot of these companies are getting down to bear basement valuations in our opinion. So, if you're a bigger company, that maybe needs an additional aspect to your business and you see a company especially looking the small cap space. I mean, my god some of these names are down near 30, 40 percent just from October. You got to start minding that area to see if you can pick up a company on the cheap.

SIMONETTI: Do you think a lot of these private equity companies, well, they are -- I mean, they've got cash but are you worried that some others won't be able to get access to credit next year?

MARTIN: It's possible. You know, this whole credit thing though to me is a little bit overblown, you know, now whether you believe Secretary Mnuchin about, you know, making these calls and making sure liquidities out there and everybody is able to get their money and their access, that's one thing but the reality is to me the credit markets are not really that frozen yet and then not showing signs of freezing.

And one of the best things that happened in this market selloff is rates have started to come down again. And it's not like credit is dried up. Yes, spreads have blown out a little bit but not terribly so if you look at how financials have performed, if you look at oil stock have performed, crude oil is down big. So, it's not yet that crisis motor. And let's say indications that there's going to be a crisis mode yet, so I'm not too worried about that aspect of things.

LAYFIELD: Scott, you got such a wonderful take on the markets. One of the reasons I enjoy listening to you every time I see you on T.V. but --

MARTIN: Thanks.

LAYFIELD: -- besides from small caps, are you staying away from -- looking at small caps, what are you buying right now and are you staying away from tariffs sensitive stocks like in Apple who if the tariffs get ramped up could lose their supply chain?

MARTIN: Yes. You know, there's going to be an opportunity I think in those areas. You know, we've talked a lot about industrials. I think we've been on a couple of shows together talking about industrial stocks because they just got thrown out with the bathtub, the baby, the bathwater, everything in the bathroom really because, you know, this whole tariff war thing was really getting accelerated and you look at companies like Caterpillar, Deere, 3M, they just got totally tossed.

And those are good buying opportunities. And if you look at how those three companies have performed versus the S&P 500 over the last 30 days they've been outperforming. So, in our opinion those are good areas to start looking to pick up because I think a lot of that bad news, John, is already in those stocks.

SIMONETTI: Let's talk retail, we spend what? $850 billion this holiday season but not at Sears, not at J.C. Penney. It's deadline day for Sears bid to acquire the company. They're doing bankruptcy court today at 4:00. J.C. Penney is $0.97, J.C. Penney is a penny stock. What do you make of the retail?

MARTIN: Yes. I don't think that's what J.C. Penney had in mind when they name the company back in the day. I'll tell you. Look, these days, Lauren, you've got to stay on top of your game if you're in retail. I mean, retail is very kind of especially focused now. I mean, you look at some of the new companies that are out there like Canada Goose for example, you know, that stock has done very well because of -- especially Under Armour has even come back a little bit from the dead because of their specialty focus.

But consumers are fickle. So, if we're in retail right now, we're staying away from big box and we own Amazon just because the dominance there and John knows this too, we've looked a couple nibbles or taken a couple bites at Wal-Mart as well because of their dominance in the space.

SIMONETTI: Hey, Scott, where is Sienna right now? Because we want to give her special shout-out, she turns eight years old today? Happy birthday. Oh.

MARTIN: Oh, yes. Thank you, guys. You're so sweet. There's a picture of her. Yes. I actually even took that picture, so not only picking stocks but taking pictures. Yes. She's at home watching the -- she's at home watching the T.V. waiting for daddy to come back home and spend her birthday with her. So happy birthday, sweetheart. She's eight years old today. And we really appreciate it.

SIMONETTI: You're done with us. Go spend the day with Sienna. Thank you Scott Martin.

MARTIN: See you, guys.

SIMONETTI: All right. The President is tweeting again and it is a long one. It's on trade. urn:contentItem:5Y73-W101-JBCN-40YK-00000-00california primary 2020;national race, state focus2020-02-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:21ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1california primary 2020national race, state focusCasey Tolan; Bay Area News Group

Californians tuning into the Democratic presidential debates over the past nine months have watched candidates in the shrinking field clash again and again over such issues as health care, the economy, and who is best prepared to take on President Donald Trump.

But even as the state’s delegate-rich March 3 primary nears — and millions of voters here already have their ballots — there has been far less focus on the issues that will most directly shape California’s future, from tackling our skyrocketing housing prices and fighting deadly wildfires, to dealing with Silicon Valley’s tech giants and reforming our legal immigration system.

Here’s a primer on what the presidential hopefuls have proposed on those crucial topics for California.

Housing affordability and homelessness

Housing has long been ignored on the national political stage, but a number of candidates have rolled out sweeping plans to deal with the escalating housing prices and staggering homelessness that have struck cities across the country.

Experts say building more affordable housing is a key to lowering housing costs in places such as California, and several candidates would invest huge federal sums to do so. Sen. Bernie Sanders would go the furthest, proposing an investment of $2.5 trillion over 10 years to build and rehabilitate nearly 10 million affordable homes over the next decade. That’s a staggering amount, considering the U.S. is building about 1.3 million housing units a year.

Sen. Elizabeth Warren would invest $500 billion, in what the accounting firm Moody’s found would create more

than 3 million new affordable housing units and reduce rents by 10%. Former hedge fund chief Tom Steyer would spend $470 billion.

“The solutions and numbers may feel very big, and even overwhelming, but this is the scale of the problem,” said David Zisser, the associate director of the affordable housing advocacy group Housing California. “I suspect that $2.5 trillion (that Sanders is proposing) is probably about right.”

Not surprisingly, the party’s most progressive candidates would fund their fix by taxing the rich.

Warren would change the estate tax, while Sanders would use a wealth tax on the richest 0.1% of Americans. His plan also calls for a 25% house-flipping tax on non-owner-occupied property sold within five years of purchase, and a 2% tax on the value of vacant homes.

Experts warn throwing money at affordable housing won’t go that far without also changing local zoning rules that limit where apartment buildings can be built.

Warren, Steyer and former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg would give grants to cities that reform those zoning practices, while former South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Sanders would use a stick instead of a carrot, making federal housing or transportation funds to cities contingent on zoning reform.

Other candidates take a different tack by focusing on renters, with proposals from Sen. Amy Klobuchar, Bloomberg, Buttigieg, Sanders and others to greatly increase the availability of housing vouchers — federal funding helping low-income people pay their rent.

In one of the most drastic proposals, Sanders has called for a national rent-control law capping annual rent increases at 3% or 1.5 times the rate of inflation — more stringent than a similar California law passed last year — even though some experts warn that would stifle new housing construction. None of the other candidates support that idea.

But they do offer a variety of unique proposals. Buttigieg, for example, has put forward a program in which the federal government would give grants to cities to purchase abandoned or foreclosed homes and give them to low-income people who live in historically redlined or racially segregated areas. After 10 years of living in the home as their primary residence, the “homesteader” would fully own the property.

Former Vice President Joe Biden’s campaign says he would focus on policies that get homeless people into homes as quickly as possible instead of making shelter a condition of staying sober or participating in other programs.

And Warren would deny federal grants to police departments that arrest homeless people for living on the streets.

All of the candidates would go further than Trump, who has talked tough about cracking down on homelessness in California without laying out many specifics, cut funding for public housing repairs in his proposed budgets, and pushed state and local governments to cut regulations that get in the way of building affordable housing.

Fighting wildfires

All of the candidates have outlined policies to slash U.S. carbon emissions and fight climate change. But some have also focused on what the federal government can do to support California and other wildfire-prone Western states facing increasingly deadly and costly wildfires — many of which were sparked by damaged power lines from PG&E and other utilities.

The president can play a big role in fighting wildfires in the state, because 57% of California forests are owned and managed by the feds.

Ken Pimlott, a former Cal Fire chief, said the federal government should be investing more on fire prevention efforts instead of just supporting the state after huge fires break out.

“Historically, it has been state and local governments working in these areas — but with the size of the problem we’re facing, this is clearly a federal issue, too,” Pimlott said.

Steyer — the only Californian still in the race — has called for spending a total of $130 billion on forest health and fire safety as well as other agricultural policies. The fires that have devastated communities around California “serve as a reminder of how uncertain our future will be if we don’t address the climate crisis immediately,” Steyer said.

Bloomberg has come out with the most specific plan, calling for doubling federal funding to manage forests and to help communities protect themselves against fires to $10 billion, with half of that going to forest restoration and mitigation work. He would also increase Federal Emergency Management Agency funding for fireproofing homes.

Sanders is the only candidate who’s called for a public takeover of the California utility giant Pacific Gas and Electric Co., criticizing the company for prioritizing corporate payouts over fire safety in an online video ad released last week.

Warren, Bloomberg and Klobuchar have called for federal investments in microgrid technology — energy systems disconnected from the main electricity grid — which experts say can help reduce fire risk and avoid the blackouts that plagued Northern California during last year’s fire season.

Several of the candidates would start new programs to put more people to work defending against fires.

Bloomberg calls for a Wildfire Corps, a team of thousands of workers who would be trained in leading fire resilience work. Steyer has a similar proposal for a Civilian Climate Corps.

Trump has urged California to improve its forest management — memorably, calling for the state to “rake” its forests — and approved disaster relief funds for communities devastated by fires. But he’s done little to change the federal government’s approach to wildfires.

Regulating Big Tech

The Democratic candidates agree that tech giants like Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple have too much power. But they’re divided on what to do about it.

Two contenders — Warren and Sanders — have endorsed breaking up those companies, in a seismic shift for Silicon Valley.

Warren has championed the idea, laying out a plan to break up companies with revenue of more than $25 billion that offer online marketplaces while participating on those platforms — like Amazon selling its own products.

That would bring balance to an industry where a few companies have “bulldozed competition, used our private information for profit, and tilted the playing field against everyone else,” Warren argues in her plan.

The other candidates have called for a variety of new regulations on the tech industry and said they’d be open to breaking up companies in some cases, but none would go as far as Warren or Sanders.

Biden said he would let the Justice Department, “not politics,” decide which antitrust cases to bring. Bloomberg has said Warren and Sanders don’t “know what they’re talking about” on the issue, although he’d back some more limited breakups.

Several candidates also have called for amending or ending laws related to online misinformation. Warren has proposed “tough civil and criminal penalties” for people who knowingly share false information about when and how to vote in U.S. elections.

Currently, under section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, tech companies can’t be held legally responsible for what their users post.

Biden has called for repealing that law, while Bloomberg has suggested he wants to amend it.

And many of the candidates have called for new regulations on data privacy, although there are few specifics.

Buttigieg wants to pass a federal privacy law that requires companies to limit and protect the user data they collect, while Klobuchar has suggested taxing companies that exploit user data.

What about President Trump? He has sounded off about bias among the big tech companies, and his Department of Justice has launched a major investigation into whether the firms have pushed anti-competitive policies.

Legal immigration and H-1B visas

All of the candidates have opposed Trump’s crackdown on undocumented immigrants and called for an end to practices like separating migrant families at the border. But there’s been far less conversation about reforming the legal immigration system, even though the large majority of immigrants in California and around the country enter the country legally.

Only a few of the candidates have weighed in on the issue of H-1B visas — the program that lets highly skilled foreigners work in the U.S. and has helped Silicon Valley companies recruit hundreds of thousands of employees. The program has faced uncertainty under Trump, and critics say it allows outsourcing companies to replace American workers with lower-paid foreigners.

Bloomberg and Steyer support raising the annual 85,000 cap on H-1B visas — a limit that’s reached within days of applications opening each year. Klobuchar has also introduced legislation in the Senate to more than double the number of visas available.

Several of the candidates would pair those increases with reforms to the system. Bloomberg would raise the cap while putting in place “stronger wage requirements” and ensuring U.S. workers aren’t displaced, and he’s also proposing a “startup visa” for international entrepreneurs, similar to a program in Canada.

“Whether they are starting businesses in Silicon Valley or on Main Street, job-creating immigrants should be welcomed to the U.S. and not sent away to our competitors,” the former mayor says in his plan.

Sanders’ campaign said he would require employers to pay substantially higher wages for H-1B visa-holders, and make them portable between jobs “so workers are not trapped at a sponsoring employer.” He would also put in place tougher enforcement standards to ensure H-1B visa holders aren’t replacing American workers.

In another reform, Buttigieg, Sanders and Steyer said they’d allow the spouses of H-1B visa holders to work — a direct contrast with the Trump administration, which is moving to revoke spouses’ work authorization.

Beyond H-1B visas, Biden and Bloomberg would both get rid of caps that limit how many employment-based green cards are given out each year to citizens of any one country, which have led to huge backlogs for immigrants from China and India. They’d also set up procedures to adjust the number of employment visas available based on unemployment and other economic conditions in the U.S.

That’s a smart idea for modernizing our immigration policy, said Sarah Pierce, an analyst with the nonpartisan Migration Policy Institute in Washington.

“We need a system that’s dynamic and responds to the market, instead of this ridiculous system that’s been set in statute for decades,” she said. “The process should be a lot more thoughtful.”

Contact Casey Tolan at 510-208-6425.

But some have also focused on what the federal government can do to support California and other wildfire-prone Western states facing increasingly deadly and costly wildfires — many of which were sparked by damaged power lines from PG&E and other utilities.

The president can play a big role in fighting wildfires in the state, because 57% of California forests are owned and managed by the feds.

Ken Pimlott, a former Cal Fire chief, said the federal government should be investing more on fire prevention efforts instead of just supporting the state after huge fires break out.

“Historically, it has been state and local governments working in these areas — but with the size of the problem we’re facing, this is clearly a federal issue, too,” Pimlott said.

Steyer — the only Californian still in the race — has called for spending a total of $130 billion on forest health and fire safety as well as other agricultural policies. The fires that have devastated communities around California “serve as a reminder of how uncertain our future will be if we don’t address the climate crisis immediately,” Steyer said.

Bloomberg has come out with the most specific plan, calling for doubling federal funding to manage forests and to help communities protect themselves against fires to $10 billion, with half of that going to forest restoration and mitigation work. He would also increase Federal Emergency Management Agency funding for fireproofing homes.

Sanders is the only candidate who’s called for a public takeover of the California utility giant Pacific Gas and Electric Co., criticizing the company for prioritizing corporate payouts over fire safety in an online video ad released last week.

Warren, Bloomberg and Klobuchar have called for federal investments in microgrid technology — energy systems disconnected from the main electricity grid — which experts say can help reduce fire risk and avoid the blackouts that plagued Northern California during last year’s fire season.

Several of the candidates would start new programs to put more people to work defending against fires.

Bloomberg calls for a Wildfire Corps, a team of thousands of workers who would be trained in leading fire resilience work. Steyer has a similar proposal for a Civilian Climate Corps.

Trump has urged California to improve its forest management — memorably, calling for the state to “rake” its forests — and approved disaster relief funds for communities devastated by fires. But he’s done little to change the federal government’s approach to wildfires.

Regulating Big Tech

The Democratic candidates agree that tech giants like Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple have too much power. But they’re divided on what to do about it.

Two contenders — Warren and Sanders — have endorsed breaking up those companies, in a seismic shift for Silicon Valley.

Warren has championed the idea, laying out a plan to break up companies with revenue of more than $25 billion that offer online marketplaces while participating on those platforms — like Amazon selling its own products.

That would bring balance to an industry where a few companies have “bulldozed competition, used our private information for profit, and tilted the playing field against everyone else,” Warren argues in her plan.

Californians tuning into the Democratic presidential debates over the past nine months have watched candidates in the shrinking field clash again and again over such issues as health care, the economy, and who is best prepared to take on President Donald Trump.

But even as the state’s delegate-rich March 3 primary nears — and millions of voters here already have their ballots — there has been far less focus on the issues that will most directly shape California’s future, from tackling our skyrocketing housing prices and fighting deadly wildfires, to dealing with Silicon Valley’s tech giants and reforming our legal immigration system.

Here’s a primer on what the presidential hopefuls have proposed on those crucial topics for California.

Housing affordability and homelessness

Housing has long been ignored on the national political stage, but a number of candidates have rolled out sweeping plans to deal with the escalating housing prices and staggering homelessness that have struck cities across the country.

Experts say building more affordable housing is a key to lowering housing costs in places such as California, and several candidates would invest huge federal sums to do so. Sen. Bernie Sanders would go the furthest, proposing an investment of $2.5 trillion over 10 years to build and rehabilitate nearly 10 million affordable homes over the next decade. That’s a staggering amount, considering the U.S. is building about 1.3 million housing units a year.

Sen. Elizabeth Warren would invest $500 billion, in what the accounting firm Moody’s found would create more

than 3 million new affordable housing units and reduce rents by 10%. Former hedge fund chief Tom Steyer would spend $470 billion.

“The solutions and numbers may feel very big, and even overwhelming, but this is the scale of the problem,” said David Zisser, the associate director of the affordable housing advocacy group Housing California. “I suspect that $2.5 trillion (that Sanders is proposing) is probably about right.”

Not surprisingly, the party’s most progressive candidates would fund their fix by taxing the rich.

Warren would change the estate tax, while Sanders would use a wealth tax on the richest 0.1% of Americans. His plan also calls for a 25% house-flipping tax on non-owner-occupied property sold within five years of purchase, and a 2% tax on the value of vacant homes.

Experts warn throwing money at affordable housing won’t go that far without also changing local zoning rules that limit where apartment buildings can be built.

Warren, Steyer and former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg would give grants to cities that reform those zoning practices, while former South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Sanders would use a stick instead of a carrot, making federal housing or transportation funds to cities contingent on zoning reform.

Other candidates take a different tack by focusing on renters, with proposals from Sen. Amy Klobuchar, Bloomberg, Buttigieg, Sanders and others to greatly increase the availability of housing vouchers — federal funding helping low-income people pay their rent.

In one of the most drastic proposals, Sanders has called for a national rent-control law capping annual rent increases at 3% or 1.5 times the rate of inflation — more stringent than a similar California law passed last year — even though some experts warn that would stifle new housing construction. None of the other candidates support that idea.

But they do offer a variety of unique proposals. Buttigieg, for example, has put forward a program in which the federal government would give grants to cities to purchase abandoned or foreclosed homes and give them to low-income people who live in historically redlined or racially segregated areas. After 10 years of living in the home as their primary residence, the “homesteader” would fully own the property.

Former Vice President Joe Biden’s campaign says he would focus on policies that get homeless people into homes as quickly as possible instead of making shelter a condition of staying sober or participating in other programs.

And Warren would deny federal grants to police departments that arrest homeless people for living on the streets.

All of the candidates would go further than Trump, who has talked tough about cracking down on homelessness in California without laying out many specifics, cut funding for public housing repairs in his proposed budgets, and pushed state and local governments to cut regulations that get in the way of building affordable housing.

Californians tuning into the Democratic presidential debates over the past nine months have watched candidates in the shrinking field clash again and again over such issues as health care, the economy, and who is best prepared to take on President Donald Trump.

But even as the state’s delegate-rich March 3 primary nears — and millions of voters here already have their ballots — there has been far less focus on the issues that will most directly shape California’s future, from tackling our skyrocketing housing prices and fighting deadly wildfires, to dealing with Silicon Valley’s tech giants and reforming our legal immigration system.

Here’s a primer on what the presidential hopefuls have proposed on those crucial topics for California.

Housing affordability and homelessness

Housing has long been ignored on the national political stage, but a number of candidates have rolled out sweeping plans to deal with the escalating housing prices and staggering homelessness that have struck cities across the country.

Experts say building more affordable housing is a key to lowering housing costs in places such as California, and several candidates would invest huge federal sums to do so. Sen. Bernie Sanders would go the furthest, proposing an investment of $2.5 trillion over 10 years to build and rehabilitate nearly 10 million affordable homes over the next decade. That’s a staggering amount, considering the U.S. is building about 1.3 million housing units a year.

Sen. Elizabeth Warren would invest $500 billion, in what the accounting firm Moody’s found would create more

than 3 million new affordable housing units and reduce rents by 10%. Former hedge fund chief Tom Steyer would spend $470 billion.

“The solutions and numbers may feel very big, and even overwhelming, but this is the scale of the problem,” said David Zisser, the associate director of the affordable housing advocacy group Housing California. “I suspect that $2.5 trillion (that Sanders is proposing) is probably about right.”

Not surprisingly, the party’s most progressive candidates would fund their fix by taxing the rich.

Warren would change the estate tax, while Sanders would use a wealth tax on the richest 0.1% of Americans. His plan also calls for a 25% house-flipping tax on non-owner-occupied property sold within five years of purchase, and a 2% tax on the value of vacant homes.

Experts warn throwing money at affordable housing won’t go that far without also changing local zoning rules that limit where apartment buildings can be built.

Warren, Steyer and former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg would give grants to cities that reform those zoning practices, while former South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Sanders would use a stick instead of a carrot, making federal housing or transportation funds to cities contingent on zoning reform.

Other candidates take a different tack by focusing on renters, with proposals from Sen. Amy Klobuchar, Bloomberg, Buttigieg, Sanders and others to greatly increase the availability of housing vouchers — federal funding helping low-income people pay their rent.

In one of the most drastic proposals, Sanders has called for a national rent-control law capping annual rent increases at 3% or 1.5 times the rate of inflation — more stringent than a similar California law passed last year — even though some experts warn that would stifle new housing construction. None of the other candidates support that idea.

But they do offer a variety of unique proposals. Buttigieg, for example, has put forward a program in which the federal government would give grants to cities to purchase abandoned or foreclosed homes and give them to low-income people who live in historically redlined or racially segregated areas. After 10 years of living in the home as their primary residence, the “homesteader” would fully own the property.

Former Vice President Joe Biden’s campaign says he would focus on policies that get homeless people into homes as quickly as possible instead of making shelter a condition of staying sober or participating in other programs.

And Warren would deny federal grants to police departments that arrest homeless people for living on the streets.

All of the candidates would go further than Trump, who has talked tough about cracking down on homelessness in California without laying out many specifics, cut funding for public housing repairs in his proposed budgets, and pushed state and local governments to cut regulations that get in the way of building affordable housing.

Fighting wildfires

All of the candidates have outlined policies to slash U.S. carbon emissions and fight climate change. But some have also focused on what the federal government can do to support California and other wildfire-prone Western states facing increasingly deadly and costly wildfires — many of which were sparked by damaged power lines from PG&E and other utilities.

The president can play a big role in fighting wildfires in the state, because 57% of California forests are owned and managed by the feds.

Ken Pimlott, a former Cal Fire chief, said the federal government should be investing more on fire prevention efforts instead of just supporting the state after huge fires break out.

“Historically, it has been state and local governments working in these areas — but with the size of the problem we’re facing, this is clearly a federal issue, too,” Pimlott said.

Steyer — the only Californian still in the race — has called for spending a total of $130 billion on forest health and fire safety as well as other agricultural policies. The fires that have devastated communities around California “serve as a reminder of how uncertain our future will be if we don’t address the climate crisis immediately,” Steyer said.

Bloomberg has come out with the most specific plan, calling for doubling federal funding to manage forests and to help communities protect themselves against fires to $10 billion, with half of that going to forest restoration and mitigation work. He would also increase Federal Emergency Management Agency funding for fireproofing homes.

Sanders is the only candidate who’s called for a public takeover of the California utility giant Pacific Gas and Electric Co., criticizing the company for prioritizing corporate payouts over fire safety in an online video ad released last week.

Warren, Bloomberg and Klobuchar have called for federal investments in microgrid technology — energy systems disconnected from the main electricity grid — which experts say can help reduce fire risk and avoid the blackouts that plagued Northern California during last year’s fire season.

Several of the candidates would start new programs to put more people to work defending against fires.

Bloomberg calls for a Wildfire Corps, a team of thousands of workers who would be trained in leading fire resilience work. Steyer has a similar proposal for a Civilian Climate Corps.

Trump has urged California to improve its forest management — memorably, calling for the state to “rake” its forests — and approved disaster relief funds for communities devastated by fires. But he’s done little to change the federal government’s approach to wildfires.

Regulating Big Tech

The Democratic candidates agree that tech giants like Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple have too much power. But they’re divided on what to do about it.

Two contenders — Warren and Sanders — have endorsed breaking up those companies, in a seismic shift for Silicon Valley.

Warren has championed the idea, laying out a plan to break up companies with revenue of more than $25 billion that offer online marketplaces while participating on those platforms — like Amazon selling its own products.

That would bring balance to an industry where a few companies have “bulldozed competition, used our private information for profit, and tilted the playing field against everyone else,” Warren argues in her plan.

The other candidates have called for a variety of new regulations on the tech industry and said they’d be open to breaking up companies in some cases, but none would go as far as Warren or Sanders.

Biden said he would let the Justice Department, “not politics,” decide which antitrust cases to bring. Bloomberg has said Warren and Sanders don’t “know what they’re talking about” on the issue, although he’d back some more limited breakups.

Several candidates also have called for amending or ending laws related to online misinformation. Warren has proposed “tough civil and criminal penalties” for people who knowingly share false information about when and how to vote in U.S. elections.

Currently, under section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, tech companies can’t be held legally responsible for what their users post.

Biden has called for repealing that law, while Bloomberg has suggested he wants to amend it.

And many of the candidates have called for new regulations on data privacy, although there are few specifics.

Buttigieg wants to pass a federal privacy law that requires companies to limit and protect the user data they collect, while Klobuchar has suggested taxing companies that exploit user data.

What about President Trump? He has sounded off about bias among the big tech companies, and his Department of Justice has launched a major investigation into whether the firms have pushed anti-competitive policies.

All of the candidates have opposed Trump’s crackdown on undocumented immigrants and called for an end to practices like separating migrant families at the border. But there’s been far less conversation about reforming the legal immigration system, even though the large majority of immigrants in California and around the country enter the country legally.

Only a few of the candidates have weighed in on the issue of H-1B visas — the program that lets highly skilled foreigners work in the U.S. and has helped Silicon Valley companies recruit hundreds of thousands of employees. The program has faced uncertainty under Trump, and critics say it allows outsourcing companies to replace American workers with lower-paid foreigners.

Bloomberg and Steyer support raising the annual 85,000 cap on H-1B visas — a limit that’s reached within days of applications opening each year. Klobuchar has also introduced legislation in the Senate to more than double the number of visas available.

Several of the candidates would pair those increases with reforms to the system. Bloomberg would raise the cap while putting in place “stronger wage requirements” and ensuring U.S. workers aren’t displaced, and he’s also proposing a “startup visa” for international entrepreneurs, similar to a program in Canada.

“Whether they are starting businesses in Silicon Valley or on Main Street, job-creating immigrants should be welcomed to the U.S. and not sent away to our competitors,” the former mayor says in his plan.

Sanders’ campaign said he would require employers to pay substantially higher wages for H-1B visa-holders, and make them portable between jobs “so workers are not trapped at a sponsoring employer.” He would also put in place tougher enforcement standards to ensure H-1B visa holders aren’t replacing American workers.

In another reform, Buttigieg, Sanders and Steyer said they’d allow the spouses of H-1B visa holders to work — a direct contrast with the Trump administration, which is moving to revoke spouses’ work authorization.

Beyond H-1B visas, Biden and Bloomberg would both get rid of caps that limit how many employment-based green cards are given out each year to citizens of any one country, which have led to huge backlogs for immigrants from China and India. They’d also set up procedures to adjust the number of employment visas available based on unemployment and other economic conditions in the U.S.

That’s a smart idea for modernizing our immigration policy, said Sarah Pierce, an analyst with the nonpartisan Migration Policy Institute in Washington.

“We need a system that’s dynamic and responds to the market, instead of this ridiculous system that’s been set in statute for decades,” she said. “The process should be a lot more thoughtful.”

urn:contentItem:5Y74-B9K1-DXVP-V0DN-00000-00california primary 2020;national race, state focus2020-02-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:21ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1california primary 2020national race, state focusCasey Tolan; Bay Area News Group

Californians tuning into the Democratic presidential debates over the past nine months have watched candidates in the shrinking field clash again and again over such issues as health care, the economy, and who is best prepared to take on President Donald Trump.

But even as the state’s delegate-rich March 3 primary nears — and millions of voters here already have their ballots — there has been far less focus on the issues that will most directly shape California’s future, from tackling our skyrocketing housing prices and fighting deadly wildfires, to dealing with Silicon Valley’s tech giants and reforming our legal immigration system.

Here’s a primer on what the presidential hopefuls have proposed on those crucial topics for California.

Housing affordability and homelessness

Housing has long been ignored on the national political stage, but a number of candidates have rolled out sweeping plans to deal with the escalating housing prices and staggering homelessness that have struck cities across the country.

Experts say building more affordable housing is a key to lowering housing costs in places such as California, and several candidates would invest huge federal sums to do so. Sen. Bernie Sanders would go the furthest, proposing an investment of $2.5 trillion over 10 years to build and rehabilitate nearly 10 million affordable homes over the next decade. That’s a staggering amount, considering the U.S. is building about 1.3 million housing units a year.

Sen. Elizabeth Warren would invest $500 billion, in what the accounting firm Moody’s found would create more

than 3 million new affordable housing units and reduce rents by 10%. Former hedge fund chief Tom Steyer would spend $470 billion.

“The solutions and numbers may feel very big, and even overwhelming, but this is the scale of the problem,” said David Zisser, the associate director of the affordable housing advocacy group Housing California. “I suspect that $2.5 trillion (that Sanders is proposing) is probably about right.”

Not surprisingly, the party’s most progressive candidates would fund their fix by taxing the rich.

Warren would change the estate tax, while Sanders would use a wealth tax on the richest 0.1% of Americans. His plan also calls for a 25% house-flipping tax on non-owner-occupied property sold within five years of purchase, and a 2% tax on the value of vacant homes.

Experts warn throwing money at affordable housing won’t go that far without also changing local zoning rules that limit where apartment buildings can be built.

Warren, Steyer and former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg would give grants to cities that reform those zoning practices, while former South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Sanders would use a stick instead of a carrot, making federal housing or transportation funds to cities contingent on zoning reform.

Other candidates take a different tack by focusing on renters, with proposals from Sen. Amy Klobuchar, Bloomberg, Buttigieg, Sanders and others to greatly increase the availability of housing vouchers — federal funding helping low-income people pay their rent.

In one of the most drastic proposals, Sanders has called for a national rent-control law capping annual rent increases at 3% or 1.5 times the rate of inflation — more stringent than a similar California law passed last year — even though some experts warn that would stifle new housing construction. None of the other candidates support that idea.

But they do offer a variety of unique proposals. Buttigieg, for example, has put forward a program in which the federal government would give grants to cities to purchase abandoned or foreclosed homes and give them to low-income people who live in historically redlined or racially segregated areas. After 10 years of living in the home as their primary residence, the “homesteader” would fully own the property.

Former Vice President Joe Biden’s campaign says he would focus on policies that get homeless people into homes as quickly as possible instead of making shelter a condition of staying sober or participating in other programs.

And Warren would deny federal grants to police departments that arrest homeless people for living on the streets.

All of the candidates would go further than Trump, who has talked tough about cracking down on homelessness in California without laying out many specifics, cut funding for public housing repairs in his proposed budgets, and pushed state and local governments to cut regulations that get in the way of building affordable housing.

Fighting wildfires

All of the candidates have outlined policies to slash U.S. carbon emissions and fight climate change. But some have also focused on what the federal government can do to support California and other wildfire-prone Western states facing increasingly deadly and costly wildfires — many of which were sparked by damaged power lines from PG&E and other utilities.

The president can play a big role in fighting wildfires in the state, because 57% of California forests are owned and managed by the feds.

Ken Pimlott, a former Cal Fire chief, said the federal government should be investing more on fire prevention efforts instead of just supporting the state after huge fires break out.

“Historically, it has been state and local governments working in these areas — but with the size of the problem we’re facing, this is clearly a federal issue, too,” Pimlott said.

Steyer — the only Californian still in the race — has called for spending a total of $130 billion on forest health and fire safety as well as other agricultural policies. The fires that have devastated communities around California “serve as a reminder of how uncertain our future will be if we don’t address the climate crisis immediately,” Steyer said.

Bloomberg has come out with the most specific plan, calling for doubling federal funding to manage forests and to help communities protect themselves against fires to $10 billion, with half of that going to forest restoration and mitigation work. He would also increase Federal Emergency Management Agency funding for fireproofing homes.

Sanders is the only candidate who’s called for a public takeover of the California utility giant Pacific Gas and Electric Co., criticizing the company for prioritizing corporate payouts over fire safety in an online video ad released last week.

Warren, Bloomberg and Klobuchar have called for federal investments in microgrid technology — energy systems disconnected from the main electricity grid — which experts say can help reduce fire risk and avoid the blackouts that plagued Northern California during last year’s fire season.

Several of the candidates would start new programs to put more people to work defending against fires.

Bloomberg calls for a Wildfire Corps, a team of thousands of workers who would be trained in leading fire resilience work. Steyer has a similar proposal for a Civilian Climate Corps.

Trump has urged California to improve its forest management — memorably, calling for the state to “rake” its forests — and approved disaster relief funds for communities devastated by fires. But he’s done little to change the federal government’s approach to wildfires.

Regulating Big Tech

The Democratic candidates agree that tech giants like Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple have too much power. But they’re divided on what to do about it.

Two contenders — Warren and Sanders — have endorsed breaking up those companies, in a seismic shift for Silicon Valley.

Warren has championed the idea, laying out a plan to break up companies with revenue of more than $25 billion that offer online marketplaces while participating on those platforms — like Amazon selling its own products.

That would bring balance to an industry where a few companies have “bulldozed competition, used our private information for profit, and tilted the playing field against everyone else,” Warren argues in her plan.

The other candidates have called for a variety of new regulations on the tech industry and said they’d be open to breaking up companies in some cases, but none would go as far as Warren or Sanders.

Biden said he would let the Justice Department, “not politics,” decide which antitrust cases to bring. Bloomberg has said Warren and Sanders don’t “know what they’re talking about” on the issue, although he’d back some more limited breakups.

Several candidates also have called for amending or ending laws related to online misinformation. Warren has proposed “tough civil and criminal penalties” for people who knowingly share false information about when and how to vote in U.S. elections.

Currently, under section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, tech companies can’t be held legally responsible for what their users post.

Biden has called for repealing that law, while Bloomberg has suggested he wants to amend it.

And many of the candidates have called for new regulations on data privacy, although there are few specifics.

Buttigieg wants to pass a federal privacy law that requires companies to limit and protect the user data they collect, while Klobuchar has suggested taxing companies that exploit user data.

What about President Trump? He has sounded off about bias among the big tech companies, and his Department of Justice has launched a major investigation into whether the firms have pushed anti-competitive policies.

Legal immigration and H-1B visas

All of the candidates have opposed Trump’s crackdown on undocumented immigrants and called for an end to practices like separating migrant families at the border. But there’s been far less conversation about reforming the legal immigration system, even though the large majority of immigrants in California and around the country enter the country legally.

Only a few of the candidates have weighed in on the issue of H-1B visas — the program that lets highly skilled foreigners work in the U.S. and has helped Silicon Valley companies recruit hundreds of thousands of employees. The program has faced uncertainty under Trump, and critics say it allows outsourcing companies to replace American workers with lower-paid foreigners.

Bloomberg and Steyer support raising the annual 85,000 cap on H-1B visas — a limit that’s reached within days of applications opening each year. Klobuchar has also introduced legislation in the Senate to more than double the number of visas available.

Several of the candidates would pair those increases with reforms to the system. Bloomberg would raise the cap while putting in place “stronger wage requirements” and ensuring U.S. workers aren’t displaced, and he’s also proposing a “startup visa” for international entrepreneurs, similar to a program in Canada.

“Whether they are starting businesses in Silicon Valley or on Main Street, job-creating immigrants should be welcomed to the U.S. and not sent away to our competitors,” the former mayor says in his plan.

Sanders’ campaign said he would require employers to pay substantially higher wages for H-1B visa-holders, and make them portable between jobs “so workers are not trapped at a sponsoring employer.” He would also put in place tougher enforcement standards to ensure H-1B visa holders aren’t replacing American workers.

In another reform, Buttigieg, Sanders and Steyer said they’d allow the spouses of H-1B visa holders to work — a direct contrast with the Trump administration, which is moving to revoke spouses’ work authorization.

Beyond H-1B visas, Biden and Bloomberg would both get rid of caps that limit how many employment-based green cards are given out each year to citizens of any one country, which have led to huge backlogs for immigrants from China and India. They’d also set up procedures to adjust the number of employment visas available based on unemployment and other economic conditions in the U.S.

That’s a smart idea for modernizing our immigration policy, said Sarah Pierce, an analyst with the nonpartisan Migration Policy Institute in Washington.

“We need a system that’s dynamic and responds to the market, instead of this ridiculous system that’s been set in statute for decades,” she said. “The process should be a lot more thoughtful.”

Several of the candidates would start new programs to put more people to work defending against fires.

Bloomberg calls for a Wildfire Corps, a team of thousands of workers who would be trained in leading fire resilience work. Steyer has a similar proposal for a Civilian Climate Corps.

Trump has urged California to improve its forest management — memorably, calling for the state to “rake” its forests — and approved disaster relief funds for communities devastated by fires. But he’s done little to change the federal government’s approach to wildfires.

Regulating Big Tech

The Democratic candidates agree that tech giants like Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple have too much power. But they’re divided on what to do about it.

Two contenders — Warren and Sanders — have endorsed breaking up those companies, in a seismic shift for Silicon Valley.

Warren has championed the idea, laying out a plan to break up companies with revenue of more than $25 billion that offer online marketplaces while participating on those platforms — like Amazon selling its own products.

That would bring balance to an industry where a few companies have “bulldozed competition, used our private information for profit, and tilted the playing field against everyone else,” Warren argues in her plan.

The other candidates have called for a variety of new regulations on the tech industry and said they’d be open to breaking up companies in some cases, but none would go as far as Warren or Sanders.

Biden said he would let the Justice Department, “not politics,” decide which antitrust cases to bring. Bloomberg has said Warren and Sanders don’t “know what they’re talking about” on the issue, although he’d back some more limited breakups.

Several candidates also have called for amending or ending laws related to online misinformation. Warren has proposed “tough civil and criminal penalties” for people who knowingly share false information about when and how to vote in U.S. elections.

Currently, under section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, tech companies can’t be held legally responsible for what their users post.

Biden has called for repealing that law, while Bloomberg has suggested he wants to amend it.

And many of the candidates have called for new regulations on data privacy, although there are few specifics.

Buttigieg wants to pass a federal privacy law that requires companies to limit and protect the user data they collect, while Klobuchar has suggested taxing companies that exploit user data.

What about President Trump? He has sounded off about bias among the big tech companies, and his Department of Justice has launched a major investigation into whether the firms have pushed anti-competitive policies.

Legal immigration and H-1B visas

All of the candidates have opposed Trump’s crackdown on undocumented immigrants and called for an end to practices like separating migrant families at the border. But there’s been far less conversation about reforming the legal immigration system, even though the large majority of immigrants in California and around the country enter the country legally.

Only a few of the candidates have weighed in on the issue of H-1B visas — the program that lets highly skilled foreigners work in the U.S. and has helped Silicon Valley companies recruit hundreds of thousands of employees. The program has faced uncertainty under Trump, and critics say it allows outsourcing companies to replace American workers with lower-paid foreigners.

Bloomberg and Steyer support raising the annual 85,000 cap on H-1B visas — a limit that’s reached within days of applications opening each year. Klobuchar has also introduced legislation in the Senate to more than double the number of visas available.

Several of the candidates would pair those increases with reforms to the system. Bloomberg would raise the cap while putting in place “stronger wage requirements” and ensuring U.S. workers aren’t displaced, and he’s also proposing a “startup visa” for international entrepreneurs, similar to a program in Canada.

“Whether they are starting businesses in Silicon Valley or on Main Street, job-creating immigrants should be welcomed to the U.S. and not sent away to our competitors,” the former mayor says in his plan.

Sanders’ campaign said he would require employers to pay substantially higher wages for H-1B visa-holders, and make them portable between jobs “so workers are not trapped at a sponsoring employer.” He would also put in place tougher enforcement standards to ensure H-1B visa holders aren’t replacing American workers.

In another reform, Buttigieg, Sanders and Steyer said they’d allow the spouses of H-1B visa holders to work — a direct contrast with the Trump administration, which is moving to revoke spouses’ work authorization.

Beyond H-1B visas, Biden and Bloomberg would both get rid of caps that limit how many employment-based green cards are given out each year to citizens of any one country, which have led to huge backlogs for immigrants from China and India. They’d also set up procedures to adjust the number of employment visas available based on unemployment and other economic conditions in the U.S.

That’s a smart idea for modernizing our immigration policy, said Sarah Pierce, an analyst with the nonpartisan Migration Policy Institute in Washington.

“We need a system that’s dynamic and responds to the market, instead of this ridiculous system that’s been set in statute for decades,” she said. “The process should be a lot more thoughtful.”
