urn:contentItem:5Y1R-JV41-F03R-N4V5-00000-00Cali-Globalization2020-01-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:21ZLexisNexisCali-GlobalizationMichael Moran

Jan 21, 2020( Foreign Policy: http://www.foreignpolicy.com/ Delivered by Newstex) On Jan. 1, the new California Consumer Privacy Act[1] (CCPA) went into effect, with consequences felt far beyond the state's borders. Unlike in neighboring Las Vegas, what happens in California rarely stays in California, especially when it comes to business regulations. The CCPA is no exception.

It is the U.S. beachhead of the 2018 European Union General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), the previous effort by the EU to regulate aspects of how corporations handle personal data. By dint of California's size—it is the largest internal market in the United States and the fifth-largest economy in the world—and influence in the tech sector—the state is home to Facebook, Google, Yahoo, Cisco, and many others—the impact of the CCPA on the rest of the world could be far larger than its European cousin. Indeed, the CCPA has already lit a fire under the U.S. Congress, where a rare bipartisan push toward federal data protection legislation is underway. The effort is aimed at forestalling a state-by-state patchwork of law and, for the Republican Party at least, denying a victory to the reviled activist legislators of California. The reversal in recent years of the decadeslong trend toward a more coordinated global economic, trade, and regulatory environment has led regulators in the United States and abroad to seek new ways around populist and protectionist governments. Stateside, California has been a perfect Trojan horse.In other years, the EU's enactment of the GDPR would have spurred congressional action or trans-Atlantic talks to harmonize the legal codes of the world's two largest economic entities. The GDPR levies fines of up to 4 percent of annual revenue on companies doing business in Europe that fail to protect the personal data and privacy of EU citizens. The rule has already cost companies globally over $100 million in legal and other fees, including the rewiring of digital business plans and platforms; the hiring of chief data officers, a relatively new post necessitated by the law; and other compliance measures. Google was quickly hit with a $57 million fine in 2019. The new legislation's impact will be even greater for American firms than their European cousins. But under the current administration, it is nearly impossible to enact any new rules that could be portrayed as ceding sovereignty in legal or regulatory matters. In turn, some Democrat-led states, including New York and California, have tried to take up the cause on their own. Their behavior is not unprecedented. These states have long tried to set the tone for certain business and policy practices (New York on financial regulation and anti-corruption legislation, California and others on environmental and agricultural policy). And, in fact, there is a deep history of all sorts of states taking the lead on issues where Washington can't reach consensus. In the 1980s, for example, the states of New England banded together to fight the acid rain that resulted from coal-burning power plants in the Midwest. Massachusetts eventually sued the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to force it to enforce the 1963 Clean Air Act and won its case in the Supreme Court[2] in 2007. When the Obama administration signed the Iran nuclear deal in 2015, many states, Texas in particular, led the charge against the agreement by forcing locally based firms and pension funds to divest from companies doing business in Iran despite pledges in the deal to end U.S. economic sanctions. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo tried to spark a similar revolt, this time against fracking, by banning the technique in his state in 2014,with hopes that others would follow. But other states with shale formations—Texas, Pennsylvania, North Dakota, Colorado, and others—found the license fees and tax revenue preferable, and they show no signs of following suit. It is in California where such legislative maneuvering has had the greatest impact. California's 2007 decision to set higher fuel efficiency standards than the rest of the United States—a move affirmed by the EPA in 2009 when it issued an exemption to allow the state to exceed federal standards—defeated powerful opposition from the energy and auto industries. It forced a rapid increase, again due to the state's size, in the average miles per gallon of new global vehicles. The Trump administration recently revoked California's EPA exemption, but it matters little. All along, the auto industry's main objections to California's higher standard revolved around the costs involved in retooling and redesigning existing fleets. They're no more interested in retooling again for lower standards, although subsequent improvements in new U.S. cars may slow if Trump's reversal is not itself reversed by a future administration. So what, exactly, will the CCPA bring? Generally, for anyone doing business online, from Google and Facebook down to small shop with a simple email marketing account, the CCPA will matter, even if the company has already spent significantly to comply with the GDPR.The California Department of Justice warns that even GDPR-complaint companies will have additional obligations under the CCPA. For instance, the GDPR requires all firms to do an audit of their data policies to create records of what information they are retaining. Under the CCPA, there is an entirely different requirement for data mapping, which will mean tweaks to any current GDPR-compliant practices. Both the CCPA and the GDPR require companies to respond to individual requests for access to personal information, including demands that such information be erased (part of the EU's assertion of a 'right to be forgotten'). But the CCPA defines 'personal data' somewhat differently than the GDPR. The California Department of Justice advisory[3] notes that 'businesses may need to review and reconcile the different definitions of personal information and applicable rules on verification of consumer requests.' The bottom line: lots more work (and more fees) for corporate legal teams—and that's before you get sued by the state regulatory body or through a consumer class action group. For multinationals, the GDPR has not been the existential blow its harshest critics predicted, but it has added complications and costs to operating in the big European market. The Harvard Business Review notes[4] that 'these new powers come with new responsibilities and new costs for users, not least ofwhich areballooning budgets for government data management and enforcement bureaucracies worldwide.' No matter how you slice that, higher taxes go hand in hand with the costs corporations bear to comply with the law, with those costs invariably passed along to consumers.Meanwhile, the new law has already stirred unusual activity among the typically inert mass of humanity Americans refer to as Congress. Late last year, four Democratic senators, including Maria Cantwell, the top Democrat on the Senate Commerce, Science, and Transportation Committee, introduced a new national privacy bill: the Consumer Online Privacy Rights Act[5]. The bill aims to provide consumers with a digital version of Miranda rights and, for companies that don't properly adjust their policies, set up steep penalties to encourage compliance. Republicans countered with their own bill, sponsored by Sen. Roger Wicker of Mississippi, which raises the bar for consumer consent. Rather than rely on legalistic disclosures like Cantwell's version, the Republican alternative would effectively forbid the collection or transfer of personal data unless consumers specifically opt in to allow it. Meanwhile, a proposal in the House, sponsored by two California Democratic representatives, Anna Eshoo and Zoe Lofgren, would create an independent federal agency to enforce privacy protections and investigate abuses. It remains unclear whether such politically fraught legislation can pass in a presidential election year—or whether Trump would sign it if it did. He has shown little love for initiatives born in California and has lashed out frequently at Big Tech. Whatever becomes of the CCPA and the current proposals in Congress, it is clear that global regulators and other stewards of good governance view the Golden State as a golden opportunity. A recent move among European central bankers to create green financing standards has already received pledges of related action from California and other green-tinted U.S. states. California is also leading, with New York, in seeking to create standards on so-called ESG data (Environment, Social, and Governance) that corporations release to financial data firms like Bloomberg and Thomson Reuters to burnish their green credentials. The current unregulated system allows companies to pick and choose what they report to greenwash their reputations. Environmentalists and activists on corporate transparency see little hope that the Trump administration would push forward on such initiatives, making California once again the promised land. urn:contentItem:5Y33-43T1-DY2T-81RW-00000-00Callaghan: Time to send the tech titans back to school2019-07-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:21ZLexisNexisCOLUMNISTSCallaghan: Time to send the tech titans back to school

Recently, American regulators announced they would levy a record $5 billion fine on Facebook for privacy breaches. Since Facebook can cover that ticket with one month's revenue, and their stock price actually rose on the news of the fine, what lessons can we expect them to learn from such a light slap on the wrist? Here's a modest proposal to make them behave better: It's time for the giants of technology to go back to school.

The 13-figure fine relates to Facebook giving Cambridge Analytica access to users' data without consent during the run-up to the last U.S. election. This aside, Facebook has been in the news lately for all the wrong reasons. CEO Mark Zuckerberg was called to testify before the U.S. and U.K. governments to explain how his app might be involved in election tampering, a series of bugs have exposed private user data, and lawsuits have attacked everything from biased advertising to inflated viewership numbers.

What the wizards of Silicon Valley need is a good grounding in the social sciences and humanities.

In fairness, these scandals aren't limited to Facebook: Last summer, Google was given a record-breaking $5-billion fine for breaking European Union antitrust rules, and earlier this year Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey admitted his company's handling of bullying was a "huge fail."

A clear picture is emerging of big tech behaving badly.

For several years, these companies have built unprecedented power in more corners of our lives. This can be positive - connecting old friends, and making shopping easier. It can also be negative: In 2014, Facebook secretly experimented on 700,000 users, trying to change their behaviour by altering the tone of the news updates those users received. These problems suggest that tech companies simply haven't been taught how to wield their massive new power.

The best way to teach them is not with barely noticeable fines, nor with more courses in computer science, engineering or management. In fact, what the wizards of Silicon Valley need is a good grounding in the social sciences and humanities.

It is common these days to push science and technology education as a cure-all for our changing world, but this is leaving the leaders of tomorrow under-prepared. Call me biased, but I'd suggest that current and future tech tycoons begin with a course in anthropology.

Jack Dorsey, CEO of Twitter, admitted his company's handling of bullying was a 'huge fail.'

One of the best things about that subject is that it relieves you of the belief that all problems are technical, and can be engineered away. Instead, you learn that human beings are complicated creatures and that there is power and meaning in every relationship. Even dot-com billionaires might be surprised at how abstract theories can be used to understand future problems we can't anticipate in the present.

Of course, we users share some blame for the corrosive role of technology in our lives: We use too many apps uncritically, and give power to tech companies that we would never give to a traditional firm. Would you tell Coca-Cola the names of all your friends, or share your phone records with Esso? And sure, tech firms can improve their corporate citizenship just like any other firm can. But for now, at least, their incentive to change is vanishingly small, and it's not clear they could change even if they wanted to.

For years, Silicon Valley magnates have approached social media as a technological tool instead of a social one. It now seems clear that this generation of tech titans desperately lacks the wisdom and humility that comes from studying social science. We are now starting to see just why this is a problem, and the enormous potential for things to go wrong. After all, those who don't learn from history class - and ethics, and psychology, and anthropology class - are doomed to repeat it. Back to school, Mr. Zuckerberg.

Mike Callaghan is a Canadian anthropologist who lives in Zurich, Switzerland.

urn:contentItem:5WP2-0K61-F0J6-J4BM-00000-00Call for shake-up of data laws rather than break-up of big tech;Legislation2019-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:21ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 3Call for shake-up of data laws rather than break-up of big techLegislationDavid Marin-Guzman

Regulators should focus less on curbing the dominance of the big tech companies and more on reforming the data laws that allowed them to become so big in the first place, experts said.

Microsoft managing director Steven Worrall told The Australian Financial Review Innovation Summit on Monday that any competition review should consider whether to break up platforms that have got too big to regulate, although he declined to comment about any specific company.

However, Mr Worrall stressed the importance of privacy rights and making data more transparent so consumers knew what they were exchanging. "We do feel more regulation is needed in the tech space to address very reasonable concerns around privacy and unintended consequences of the use of these platforms." He said in the absence of transparency about data use "it's reasonable that platforms should be able to held to account".

CSIRO's Data 61 chief executive Adrian Turner said suggestions of breaking up the big tech companies such as Facebook and Google were misplaced. "The question we should be asking is how did those companies get so big ..." Mr Turner said. He said part of the response was understanding the data economics underpinning the companies and taking steps to make data more inclusive.

He suggested a data rights regime that would allow consumers to become more aware about what is a "fair value exchange" for their personal data.

Both men were speaking on a panel on how to ensure the benefits of innovation are shared by all and what skills are needed for the future economy.

Professor Emma Johnson, president of Science and Technology Australia, said the industry and institutions were failing to sell STEM skills to young people and there needed to be a better focus on diversity to encourage more involvement from women.

Mr Worrall said Microsoft was advancing a new "digital apprenticeship" in partnership with TAFE as a model to teach workers digital skills.

A February enrolment round had 3000 applications for 40 "apprenticeship" positions, he said, with many from adults looking to transition out of the auto industry. "We're in a middle of revolution. We're looking for new pipelines, new pathways for people to get in the industry." "The idea you can step out and go and get retrained for four years when you've got a family and you've got commitments just doesn't compute."
